PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-FIFTH PARLIAMENT
Pursuant to the Resolution of the House of Representatives passed on 16 June 1989, the House of Representatives met on Tuesday, 15 August 1989, at 2 p.m.
Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of courtesy I inform the House that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, will be absent from Question Time today on matters relating to the preparation of the Budget. Portfolio questions which would normally be addressed to the Treasurer should, in his absence, be addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Will the Minister ensure that the integrity of the Australian electoral system is protected by giving an assurance that the Government will not introduce legislation to amend the Broadcasting Act to enforce the allocation of so-called free time for political broadcasting on television and radio for elections in Australia? Also, does the Minister agree that the proposal that `third parties' be prevented by legislation-for the first time ever-from putting their views on policies before the electorate during election campaigns is undemocratic?

—I have recently received and read a report which, of course, does discuss such matters as free time on the electronic media and paid election advertising. It also discusses the issue of full disclosure of all income and expenditure of registered political parties. All I wish to say at this stage is that I have received and read the report and the Government has these matters under consideration.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is the honourable gentleman aware of the severe disruption being experienced by passengers travelling on domestic airlines as a result of the pilots dispute? What action is the Government taking with regard to this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Chifley for his question. Yes, indeed, we are acutely aware of the difficulties that are being created by this totally unjustified action by the pilots. We deplore the recent rolling strike action that the domestic aircraft pilots have taken, which, I may say, directly contravenes Australian Industrial Relations Commission directives. As is well known, I and the Government are totally committed to the centralised wages system and we would like to see the air pilots dispute resolved within that system. That system, of course, contains rights but it carries as well obligations for those within it.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to make it clear that if the pilots refuse to abide by their obligations within the centralised system the Government would support any move for the cancellation or suspension of existing pilots, awards and agreements. It must be understood that that would, of course, cancel all the rights and all the protections that are provided to them by the centralised system. If the pilots choose to go outside the system, this Government will fully support any action by the airlines to bring the dispute to an early end. The matter is quite simple and straightforward: either the pilots in this country accept the obligations of the award system that entitles them to their rights or they forfeit those rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In the light of the Minister's previous statement during the wheat marketing debate regarding the opportunity for the Australian Wheat Board to lower the freight and handling cost to wheat growers, why has the Minister threatened the Chairman of the Wheat Board and the Board generally over the Board's logical, legal and overdue action to improve the efficiency of the Brisbane and other grain terminals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to state is that I have not threatened the Australian Wheat Board. The Australian Wheat Board is meeting today to determine its attitude to this matter. The Aegean Dolphin is due to load in Brisbane on 22 August. The ship is on contract to the Wheat Board and it is to be loaded, charge including freight. The whole problem with this has to do not so much with the issue as with the timing. We have put in place a Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA)--

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Reith interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders!

—The previous Government did absolutely nothing about the waterfront or the sea, and after the study by the Inter-State Commission and a range of other studies the Government put in place the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. An in-principle agreement was thereby reached that for three months ending in September all disputes, demarcation and all the rest of it, would be put off and that a package would be delivered back to the Government. As you understand, Madam Speaker, the Government has put money on the table and the stevedoring companies are putting money on the table. Out of a work force that has now shrunk to about 5,400 A-class waterside workers, we are proposing that 3,000 positions go. If honourable members think this is a matter that can be negotiated very easily, they have another think coming. The only position I took was to inform the Wheat Board Chairman of the existence of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, saying that this was making good progress and that for the National Farmers Federation or the National Party in Queensland, where it is getting increasingly desperate, to sabotage all that work for two shifts of five men would be a very silly step indeed. This is not enough of an issue to cruel the WIRA process.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is committed to enterprise employment; this Government is committed to reforms.
Mr Lloyd interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has asked his question. He will stop interjecting.
—We will meet those commitments as long as they are not sabotaged by members of the jihad opposite.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. It refers to the very tragic balloon accident which took place in and around the Alice Springs Airport last Sunday, when 13 people were killed as a result. Can the Minister indicate the progress with the investigation of the fatal balloon accident near Alice Springs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like every other member of this House, I was very sorry to learn of the ballooning accident which occurred on Sunday. I would like to extend my condolences, and I am sure the condolences of every member of this House, to all the relatives of the accident victims. This tragic accident involved a balloon which was one of a number operating joy flights around the Alice Springs area. Witnesses reported that the balloon collided with another balloon while it was climbing and that the basket of one balloon tore the canopy of the other and the canopy began to deflate. The pilot attempted to keep the canopy inflated by using the burners. The attempt, unfortunately, was unsuccessful and the canopy collapsed. The balloon fell about 1,000 metres, fatally injuring all the passengers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is at Alice Springs to investigate the accident now. The team includes officers of the Civil Aviation Authority and the Australian Ballooning Federation. I would like to emphasise that ballooning is essentially safe but, regrettably, like all activities, it is accompanied by an element of risk. There is no truth to the report in today's media that the Civil Aviation Authority has suspended ballooning operations at Alice Springs. Regulations for flying balloons in Australia are basically the same as those applied worldwide. As charter operators, balloon operators have to obtain air operator certificates in the same way as other commercial operators of air services. Ballooning is subject to airworthiness and flight crew requirements similar to those applying to aeroplanes. Balloons must meet the airworthiness standards determined by the Civil Aviation Authority and are registered aircraft. Australian commercial balloon pilot requirements are higher than those in most other countries, notably the United States of America.

Commercial balloon operations are supervised by the Civil Aviation Authority. Balloons are not subject to the same separation requirements that are applied to aeroplanes. For practical reasons, it is not possible to direct balloons to do anything other than to land and to take off. However, balloons are fairly large and conspicuous objects which are allowed to operate only in good visual conditions.

The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation preliminary report on the accident should be available to aviation authorities by the end of the month. My Department has been advised by the Northern Territory authorities that the balloon operator held the necessary insurance coverage to meet obligations under the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Act. It is a very unfortunate accident, and I would like to again extend the condolences of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that his Department issued an instruction, dated 2 August 1989, which stipulates a course of action in direct conflict with an amendment passed by this Parliament to the Namibia and British Commonwealth ex-service legislation, now known as the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act 1989? Did he approve this departmental instruction before his trip? On what basis was it issued? Will he now withdraw the offending section 5 of the instruction? If not, why not?
—I will have the matter investigated and I will give the honourable member an answer later today.
—My question is to the Prime Minister. Could the Prime Minister advise the House of the Government's response to the current round of conflict in Lebanon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grayndler for his question. Madam Speaker, in recent days, as we are all unfortunately aware, the fighting in Lebanon has escalated, with intensified shelling in Beirut and elsewhere causing in that tragic country new and even higher levels of misery than have been experienced before. It is a tragedy that so many Lebanese are forced to live in that climate of violence and fear. The Government's very grave concern at the horrific situation in Lebanon has been emphasised on many occasions since March. On 22 May I wrote to the United Nations Secretary-General offering Australian support for any United Nations initiative in this regard. On my recent visit overseas I raised Lebanon as a matter of priority with world leaders in Europe and in the United States. I have today written to both President Bush and President Gorbachev about the Lebanon, and I will be discussing this situation with Prime Minister Rocard of France this Friday.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure I speak for all members of this House when I call on all sides to cease the violence in Lebanon. In particular, I urge Syria to stop the shelling which is killing and maiming innocent civilians. I express the hope that the Arab League, which has done so much to this point to try to secure an effective mediation of this dispute, will renew its attempt to bring the main protagonists to the negotiating table. Australia offers its firm and unequivocal support to the Arab League in its initiative.

Australia deplores kidnapping and hostage taking in any circumstances, including the particularly harrowing circumstances in Lebanon. On 2 August the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, condemned the brutal murder of Colonel Higgins, a man serving the United Nations in the cause of peace. Australia also condemns threats to execute other foreign hostages being held in Lebanon and calls for their immediate release. The Government urges all countries with influence on groups in Lebanon to use this influence to secure their release. Our embassies in Tehran and Damascus have made representations to the Iranian and Syrian foreign ministries, and we will do whatever we can to assist in obtaining their release.

The Government understands and sympathises deeply with the concerns of Australians of Lebanese origin about their homeland, about their relatives, and about their friends still in Lebanon. We have agreed to extend temporary entry permits for Lebanese visitors in Australia to the end of September, and we will keep that situation under constant review. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has instructed his Department to explore options for making available up to 1,000 additional places in our refugee and special humanitarian programs for people affected by the fighting in Lebanon.

Madam Speaker, this tragedy has been going on for too long-for some 14 years. It is a tragedy, as we know, which is compounded not only by the existing confessional differences that exist within Lebanon but also by the attitude of external forces imposing on Lebanon their own disputes and by the intervention of those external forces. We express the hope that it will be possible to achieve and commit this Government to the position of achieving in some way, firstly, a diminution of this tragedy and, hopefully, the creation of a situation where Lebanon can be restored to what it was-a country of peace in which it was possible for people of different persuasions and different beliefs to go about their lives peaceably.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the honourable gentleman give any indication of when the Federal Government will make available its guidelines for the development of the pulp and paper industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lyons for his question. I cannot give him a precise date as to when they will be available, but let me say that we do intend to develop national guidelines for bleached kraft pulp mills. We intend to do that after consultation with the States and Territories, industry and conservation groups. It is our intention that those guidelines which will emerge from that process of consultation will ensure that only those mills incorporating the world's best in process and effluent technologies will be built in Australia and that, through appropriate baseline studies that will be done and appropriate monitoring and reporting systems being put in place, we will have an industry that will satisfy the dual criteria that I hope would be accepted on both sides; that is, we want to see in this country appropriate economic development and the processing of raw materials-that is an appropriate and necessary development for this country-but I hope all of us would share as well the other criterion, that these things be done in an environmentally acceptable manner.

ANSWER.PARA: We certainly take the view that we were not prepared to accept the situation that was being put forward before under the proposed Wesley Vale project, under which we would have had 13 tonnes of organochlorins dumped daily into the ocean. That position was not acceptable, but I repeat that we are serious in trying to get these guidelines which will marry the twin criteria of desirable economic development and acceptable environmental standards. I know that the honourable gentleman has a real interest in this matter. As soon as I am able to give him a more definite date, I will be happy to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I am concerned by suggestions that the Government might have chosen an inadequate ship for the Royal Australian Navy simply on cost cutting grounds. Can the Minister assure the House that the Meko vessel selected will meet Navy's requirements under the Anzac frigate project?
—I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. Surely this is a matter for a statement from the Government, not just an answer at Question Time.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Wilson being dazzling and disruptive, like he told us in the Sunday Times. That was it, was it, Wilson? Well, thanks a lot. I suppose that dazzling piece of intervention on his part now satisfies the journalist from the Sunday Times with whom he discussed his intention to disrupt the Parliament.
—Order! The Minister will get on with the answer.
—So no doubt he will not have to do it again.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the question from the honourable gentleman, I am able to give him complete assurances in that regard. In fact, I am able to give him the assurances that were given by the Chief of Naval Staff to Cabinet-that the ship that was selected entirely met Navy's requirements and that it was completely satisfied with it. As the Chief of Naval Staff has said in a statement today-and this is again consistent with his advice to Cabinet-the Navy is totally satisfied with the Meko 200 design and is very pleased with the level of excellence it will obtain with the new light patrol frigate in terms of both design and capability. Navy's decision to recommend the selection of Amecon proceeded independently of further higher committee consideration and reflected the unanimous decision of the Chief of Naval Staff and his senior advisory committee. Admiral Hudson said in a press release:
The Navy is being provided with a ship that is marked by excellence in all its aspects.

That was his advice to Cabinet, advice that he was prepared to give publicly. Via various committee processes, that advice arrived before government. The decision was not based simply on cost. The quality of the industry package, the capacity to support the ship, the capacity to operate the ship, the management teams involved-a whole raft of considerations-went into the recommendation. Price was extremely important, of course, as it ought to be in the determination of all defence contracts. It does not have to be exclusive, but it ought to be significant. The price gap between the two tenderers was substantial. It would have been an irresponsible government that walked away from that gap in price.

Propositions for the alternative to that which was eventually successful were put before various lobbyists, including the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner. When Mr Greiner appeared here and was asked specifically what sort of cost differential he would be prepared to tolerate, what he thought a prudent government ought to be prepared to tolerate to fully benefit his State, his answer, in front of numerous witnesses, was 2 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Two per cent?

—Two per cent. In this regard I noticed also that quite recently Mr Greiner's State awarded a contract to a yard in Queensland for the construction of Sydney Harbour transport vessels. If Mr Greiner is of the view that the Newcastle yards require a particularly favourable decision outside the framework of a sensible decision on price, it would be very sensible for him to start with his own backyard before illegitimately criticising the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the areas where this ship is going to be built, both areas-Williamstown and Newcastle-are winners. Newcastle, as a result of this decision, is back in the Navy. A massive amount of major work will be done in Newcastle, both of the nature that Newcastle currently does and new work. Five frigates will be launched from Newcastle if New Zealand comes into the proposal. This is a good decision in defence terms. The Navy has a good ship, the sort of ship that it requires for the task that it has set itself in that area, and the Government has responded to the task. Australian industry has a good industry package across the board, in a number of States, ensuring that the ship will be well supported throughout its life. As far as the defence budget and the Government's Budget are concerned-I would have thought that the Opposition would have a few concerns about the efficiencies of defence expenditure-the most responsible decision was taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Defence. Did the tendering for the frigate contract involve the maintenance of the ships and equipment for a period of 25 years? In view of the contract going to Amecon in Victoria and the statement that Newcastle will share in the construction of the ships, I ask the Minister to give an assurance that Newcastle will also share in the ongoing maintenance work which will be necessary for many years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Newcastle will share in the ongoing maintenance work on this ship. I think Newcastle will also share in the ongoing maintenance work of many other ships. In fact, there is a yard now in Newcastle that is beginning to do very well out of Navy repair and refit requirements. I think that will continue because there are now a number of excellent operations in Newcastle capable of supporting the Navy. In terms of the latter part of the honourable gentleman's question, in so far as one can give assurances well beyond the period of time one could reasonably anticipate being Minister for Defence, I think I can give him those assurances.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the first part of the honourable member's question concerning through-life support, aspects of that were included in the tender process. Some aspects were more nebulous and could not be included in the tender process. The Navy remains confident that it would have had the support it needed from either the Dutch backers of their particular proposition or the German Navy backers of the Meko 200 design which was eventually successful. Sometimes that can be overstated.

The fact of the matter is that on both ships a considerable amount of equipment was common in the tender and in that regard through-life support was not dependent on either of those navies, but rather on those manufacturers. Through-life support is of lessening significance in Australia, basically because we seek to do these things ourselves in accordance with the principles of self-reliance on which defence policy is based. If one looks at a number of the other items of equipment that are in service with the armed forces, one sees that it is not their original manufacturers to which we look for through-life support and development, but rather our own industries or other people with whom we have a relationship. For example, with the Oberon submarines, we do not look particularly to the Royal Navy for through-life support. Some of the more important aspects of that we get through cooperation with the United States Navy in the combat system. One can go through a whole host of items of kit where that applies. It is not sensible to rely on through-life support from nations that are 12,000 miles away from us. Basically we have to do that work ourselves. As a result, in my view, there has been excessive emphasis on that in some of the discussions prior to the decision on the frigate project. In so far as it is important, both sides were about as good in what they offered and therefore it played little role in Cabinet consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House of the changes the Hawke Labor Government has made to the previous Government's policies affecting water and soil conservation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for his question. The Opposition has been trying to rewrite history, in a manner that Joe Stalin would have been proud of, by suggesting that the Fraser Government had in place an effective program to combat land degradation. That is simply untrue. Senators Puplick and Brownhill have misled both the public and their own leaders as both Opposition leaders have repeated the claims. I do not blame the Opposition leaders. No-one expects them to know the facts about anything much.

ANSWER.PARA: I would point out that Environment Minister Cass during the time of the Whitlam Government put in place a most comprehensive study which became known eventually as the collaborative study. That was by far the most comprehensive statement that had ever been made on soil conservation and land degradation in this country. I well remember when Mr Kevin Newman was the Minister and he was sabotaged completely by the Fraser Government. A decision was taken. In the end an extra $3m was given to the States in general purpose grants, and it was frittered away. I well remember debates here in the late 1970s in which the right honourable member for New England, among others, said that the whole question of soil conservation was really a matter for the States, because in those times I raised these matters in the Parliament.

I think that Senators Puplick and Brownhill-certainly Senator Brownhill-both confuse the national soil conservation program. What the Fraser Government had was an election gimmick to build dams which probably would have made salinity problems worse. It also provided taxation concessions for land clearing, which basically runs counter to everything we need to do with respect to the environment. What the coalition had was not a program to counter land degradation, but programs to make it worse. It was this Government that introduced the national soil conservation program, with funding increasing from that which applied in 1983-84, when we first came into government, to $23.4m this year. It was this Government that set up the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. The previous Government never had the wit, or the will, to get that together. It was one of the most important steps ever taken by a government and a shining example of the cooperation one can get.

The Prime Minister's environment statement tied together all the work that has been done for a long time, and it is very comprehensive. This is a measure of the Government's commitment to solving this major national problem-Australia's main conservation problem. This was done after years of coalition policies that only made the problem worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister a question which is supplementary to the question he answered earlier in Question Time about domestic air pilots. In light of his answer concerning pilots, will the Government and he apply the same sanctions and rules to air traffic controllers in Sydney and Melbourne, who for eight months have been disrupting Australian travellers and damaging Australia's reputation overseas as a tourist destination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I have both publicly and privately condemned the action of the air traffic controllers. But I did not satisfy myself simply with condemning them. What I did was convene a committee which consisted of people, including Mr George Polites, who I thought had the capacity to deal with this matter. They conducted discussions with both the Federal Airports Corporation and the air traffic controllers. I believe that as a result of those discussions which I initiated, where we put a very strong position to the air traffic controllers that we would not tolerate a continuation of the very damaging tactics that they were earlier employing, we have started now to move to a rectification of this situation.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say this: having condemned, as I did and as I would do again, the action of the air traffic controllers, as in many situations-not only industrial situations but also interpersonal relations-it was not a case of 100 per cent fault being exclusively with the air traffic controllers. It is fair to say that they had some legitimate concerns. In that respect I would say to the honourable member that we have taken steps to accelerate the provision of appropriate radar equipment in Melbourne and in Sydney, where the major problem area was. I am hopeful that, as a result of both the tough position that we put to the air traffic controllers and what we have done to accept our responsibility for accelerating the provision of new equipment, the situation that the honourable member rightly refers to as a problem area for Australia will be rectified. I think we have to understand that those people do have a very responsible and stressful position. They are entitled to expect that everything will be done to provide them with the best equipment at the earliest possible time. We are accepting our obligation in that respect. As I said before, in all these matters there are rights and obligations. We have accepted our obligation and I trust that in the future the air traffic controllers will accept theirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Could the Minister outline for the House moves to institute long lasting and substantial reform of the Australian waterfront and explain what implications this has for the farm sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I know that as the honourable member for Grey he has a very keen interest in the efficient operation of grain handling facilities in seaboard terminals. When I was recently in his electorate I gained an appreciation of the work that he has been doing with the people on the waterfront and also on ships. I am aware of the work that he did in conjunction with the Minister for Industrial Relations, the then Minister for Transport.

ANSWER.PARA: I take it as a central thesis that Australia is a small trading nation and that we cannot afford to have anything but a first-class transport handling system. The House will be aware, of course, that the Minister for Transport and Communications has instituted a process whereby the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission in respect of the waterfront can be put into effect. The process of reform on the waterfront is a matter of utmost concern. Huge savings can be made from the process of restructuring in our stevedoring industry and in the practices which presently characterise operations on our seaboard. The estimates of savings are anything up to $650m.

I might add that there is nothing strange or unusual about my interest in this matter, for within the responsibility that I have as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy industry reform has occupied the bulk of my time. These efforts, which will result in more flexible, efficient and competitive industries, have not always been fully welcomed, particularly by the primary industries involved.

Honourable members may not be aware that, contrary to the exaggerated image touted by the `Industrial Wish Upon a Star Club', the Australian Wheat Board and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia have negotiated, over a period of time, improved practices in the handling facilities in Western Australia. Those negotiation were characterised by a joint intent to see that the operations of these facilities was efficient and effective. I might add that this agreement between the Wheat Board and the Waterside Workers Federation has, as a central tenet, that the introduction of new technology in the grain terminals will result in further moves on manning levels.

Unfortunately, there are some elements who are not prepared to grind their way through reform. They see the waterfront as reason for calling, as I said in answer to an earlier question, a jihad in which all wharfies, all unionists, all workers could be put to the sword. Not surprisingly, the more disreputable of this hard line, yet soft-headed crowd includes the Queensland Government, the Grains Council of Australia and the National Farmers Federation. They say that they are concerned to see efficiency gains on the waterfront. They say that manning practices must change. They say that the Inter-State Commission's recommendations must be implemented. They are saying what we are saying. But what they are trying to do is bring on a political stunt to sabotage the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. How does the Minister justify wasting millions of dollars on politically motivated advertising and mailings about increased family allowances instead of spending the money on needy families and pensioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has just remarked to me that the honourable member for Cowper appears to have asked this question in recognition of how interested in and how concerned about family incomes people in his electorate are, particularly about the reforms in the area of family allowances that have come from this Government. As the honourable member would know, in the history of family payments in this country never has a standard been set in relation to family payments and never have family payments been indexed in real terms. Since child endowment was introduced in 1942, never have we had such reforms-reforms that go to the question of adequacy, to the question of equity; reforms that are sustainable in the longer terms.

ANSWER.PARA: In those circumstances, where the Government has made decisions that involve income testing and the various family payments, it is important that people be aware of the individual payments, of their potential eligibility for those payments and of the significance of the payments to them, to their living standards and to their participation in the work force.

The Government, in making information on family payments available, has been very pleased with the results. I take as an example one of the targeted payments, the family allowance supplement. This payment is now being made to more than 175,000 families. Over 400,000 children receive it. On average, each family-we are talking about low wage families-receives $45 to $50 a week. It is a significant payment. We expect that the take-up for that payment, in part as a result of our advertising, will take us towards 200,000 families before the end of this year.

It is difficult to think of a reform that is more important in terms of wages policy, tax transfer policies and, above all, family policies than the family allowance supplement. The Government would be stupid not to advertise, not to make sure that people are aware of the range of family payments, such as the family allowance supplement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. Is the Minister aware of a recent discovery by a South Australian company of a chemical which is used in the production of firm and flexible foam, thus eliminating the use of freons or chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)? Have any approaches been made to the Federal Government to assist in the production and use of this product?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for his question. I know that he is taking a very keen interest in this. In May, Wye Industries Ltd wrote to me advising of the product, and asked not for financial support but for access to people, particularly to officers of the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) in the United States, to describe the importance of the discovery in the hope that it might be developed internationally. Certainly, the reports of the product are impressive. It is a quantum leap as a chemical fire retardant. It would enable polyurethane foam to be blown without the need for CFC or any of the chlorinated hydrocarbons. As a result, I wrote to the regional director of UNEP in North America asking that it assist Wye Industries to find the most appropriate channels for environmental assessment of the discovery.

ANSWER.PARA: Since then, and following a number of press reports on the subject, I sought details of what requests had been made by Wye Industries for support. No request has been made to the Commonwealth for support through any of our research and development arrangements. Testing of the product in the United States was funded by the Adelaide Innovation Centre. The company's application for an export development grant was granted in July 1989. The most recent press report, in the Sunday Mail on 13 August, quotes the South Australian Minister for State Development and Technology, Mr Lynn Arnold, as suggesting that his Department is working to see what can be done and is, in fact, trying to find investors.

At the moment, I understand, negotiations are going on between the company and some investors in South Australia. I hope that those negotiations will be fruitful. At this stage the South Australian Government is not itself directly involved. I hope that this will be a good opportunity for Australian investors to put up `patient money' for something that I think is really a very important contribution to removing the amount of CFCs going into the atmosphere and threatening the survival of the ozone layer. I wish Wye Industries the very best of luck, and hope that it is one example where the private sector will come across. It is essentially something where the private sector ought to recognise the enormous commercial opportunities, and seek to exploit them properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support to his recent attacks upon the automobile clubs of Australia in replying to the criticism on the appalling decay of our roads. It being the fact that fuel consumed in power boats is also subject to 22.5c per litre of Federal taxes, amounting to revenue for the Government from boat owners of $100m, what contribution, if any, does the Government provide from these taxes to assist the operation of these craft or their service organisations, such as sea rescue?

—The short answer to the question is: very little. Nor should there be. I think we have made it perfectly clear that one of the fundamental reasons why excise duty of any kind has been imposed is to provide the Federal Government, the national Government, in particular with part of its total taxation structure and total taxation arrangement--
—The biggest taxing government in Australia's history.
—Order! The honourable member for Moreton!

—It is possible, then, for the Government to provide itself and, indirectly and more directly, the Australian people and the national community with the capacity to pursue all of those objectives that it sets itself as a result of its responding to the reasonable expectations that the national community has. The fact is that there is a road user charge built into the excise on fuel, and this year that road user charge will be about 5.4c per litre. That achieves about 25 per cent of the target that had been set by the Australian Automobile Association, to which the honourable member referred. It suggested that we should increase the amount of excise per litre of fuel going back into the road system by 2c. This year we have achieved 25 per cent of that objective, if the Association wants to set it as such. In the process we have also been able to increase the amount of fuel excise going directly back into roads from the Federal Government from $1.2 billion to more than $1.3 billion. So the basis upon which the general question has been formulated is quite spurious. As I have said before, the honourable member knows as well as everyone else does that the Federal Government has a tax structure which has been designed to provide the sort of revenue that is necessary to achieve national objectives. We will continue to do that and we will continue to do it well, as we have in the past.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support been drawn to the article in the Melbourne Sun of Wednesday, 9 August, in which it is alleged that Senator Alston has referred to Telecom Australia as Australia's largest sheltered workshop?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member wants to know whether I agree, the short answer is no, I definitely do not agree. I want to thank the honourable member for Hinkler for his question. In particular, Telecom now is subject to the independent regulator called Austel, whose job is to ensure Telecom performs efficiently, competes fairly in the marketplace and meets specific performance targets. Telecom also has a price cap on it set by the Government to ensure its service delivery and overall performance become more cost effective. Telecom and its staff, I believe, have responded to this challenge very positively and with great enthusiasm. Their recent achievements speak for themselves. First of all, last week the Opposition spokesman and I were present when Telecom launched its new technology called ISDN--
—Relaunched.

—It launched its new ISDN technology, which provides Australia with one of the most advanced telecommunications networks in the world. Telecom is also developing further the range of satellite based services which provide enhanced services in outback Australia, at sea and in education services. It also is at the forefront of the value-added service market where it is competing with the private sector. It has introduced a whole range of innovatory products. But I think one of the most important initiatives, which has not been discussed at all in this House before, is the development of a lot of its commercially based subsidiaries and joint ventures, which are competing very successfully in the marketplace. For example, only about two weeks ago I launched with Pacific Dunlop Ltd, Olex, a new contract that Pacific Dunlop and Telecom have won. It is a $30m contract with Pakistan. ANSWER.PARA: I remind honourable members that under this legislation-legislation that this Government brought in-the Government has ensured that Telecom competes in the market place on a fair basis. The Opposition's simple solution to handling any of these government business enterprises is to privatise them. We do not accept that as an alter- native. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable members will recall that, on 11 April 1989, I made a statement in this House reporting on the outcome of a series of inquiries into the administration of Aboriginal affairs. Those inquiries were established in response to allegations of serious shortcomings in the administration, including financial management, of the Aboriginal Development Commission and of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. At that time, while the bulk of the inquiries had been completed, I advised the House that a further report was expected from the Auditor-General in relation to some particular enterprise projects in the Aboriginal Development Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I also indicated that the Government was awaiting a final report from Mr Andrew Menzies, AM, OBE, on certain matters which had not in his view otherwise been dealt with to finality. I made the point that, pending Mr Menzies' final report, it would be inappropriate to comment on the conduct of any individual. I also made it clear that, with the bulk of the inquiries then completed, the Government felt in a position to inform the Parliament of its views and intentions concerning organisational arrangements for the future, and I advised the House of actions which the Government proposed to take, while standing ready to refine our response and undertake any further action should that be necessary when remaining reports were received.

The final report from Mr Menzies was received by the Government during the parliamentary recess. That report has four parts, but Mr Menzies has recommended, and the Government accepts, that Part 4 not be published, given that it contains only names and addresses of certain persons and one Aboriginal agency who made submissions in confidence. The report makes reference elsewhere to the inputs of the persons and agency concerned but their identities are not central to the issues discussed. Copies of Part 4 of the report have been made available to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt), the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines). For the information of honourable members, I now table in the House the final report from Mr Menzies, other than Part 4.

Honourable members will find that Part 1 of the report is an introductory chapter, including an overview. Part 2 covers the inquiries into three matters involving Mr Charles Perkins, to which I shall return shortly. Part 3 of the report deals with a number of miscellaneous allegations which Mr Menzies has investigated. In the case of two of these allegations, the report indicates that they have been referred to police for investigation. By agreement with Mr Menzies, the Auditor-General will be reporting on the other case. In none of the cases in Part 3 on which Mr Menzies himself has reported was corruption or serious illegality established. While Mr Menzies finds some cases of questionable practice, he recognises that action is already in hand to respond properly in those cases.

In Part 3 of the report, the only formal recommendation made by Mr Menzies relates to the activities of an organisation which is not a Commonwealth agency but is in receipt of Commonwealth funding. The relevant department, the Department of Community Services and Health, is acting on this recommendation. That Department is also following up the recommendation that the activities of a South Australian Aboriginal agency be reviewed.

I now turn to that part of the report which deals with matters involving Mr Charles Perkins. By way of introduction, I remind honourable members that various allegations made about Commonwealth administration in the Aboriginal affairs area over the past months have attracted a great deal of publicity. Many of the accusations have been extremely serious. Some, for example, alleged patronage, favouritism, nepotism and cronyism in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Others alleged or implied corruption. The name of Charles Perkins was linked with many of those allegations and with much of this publicity.

The facts are that none of the several inquiries conducted for the Government, including this final report from Mr Menzies, supports allegations of that kind. I advised this House in April that the Public Service Commissioner did not substantiate allegations of patronage, favouritism, nepotism and cronyism in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. None of these reports has substantiated in any way allegations of corruption. It can and should be firmly said, therefore, that these serious allegations, so prominently publicised, have been grossly unfair to Mr Perkins and to his family. There is nothing which emerges from any of these intensive inquiries to suggest that Charles Perkins ever took any action out of self-interest or self-reward. It is true that he has occasionally been a controversial figure; but only, I believe, where he saw this as important to his continuing effectiveness as a leader of his people.

Honourable members will see that this final report from Mr Menzies brings out some further shortcomings in administration in the area of Aboriginal affairs-in some cases shortcomings for which Mr Perkins, as the departmental Secretary over much of the period, has to bear ultimate responsibility. Although such shortcomings are identified, however, Mr Menzies does not find that Mr Perkins's role in any of the three issues addressed in this final report amounts to failure to fulfil his duty as an officer such that disciplinary action should or could be taken against him. I would add, Madam Speaker, that the bulk of the deficiencies identified in the various inquiries conducted for the Government were in the Aboriginal Development Commission and not in the Department for which Mr Perkins carried ultimate responsibility. And even within the Department, there would be incongruity in any attempt to find the blame for most of these deficiencies in Charles Perkins personally. As the Public Service Commissioner found, there were deficiencies in systems and procedures going well beyond the realm of Mr Perkins's personal responsibility.

There is only one of the three issues relating to Mr Perkins on which I wish to comment further. This relates to the source of the $50 which Mr Perkins paid for taxi fares for some of the persons who were demonstrating outside the Returned Services League headquarters on 9 September 1988. In the conclusions in his report, Mr Menzies expressed regret that Mr Perkins had refused to disclose to him the source of this $50. The report notes at paragraph 3.10 that Mr Perkins gave an `unequivocal assurance that the $50 used for the taxi fares did not come from any political source at home or abroad or from any corporation or organisation. Neither did the money come from any official source'.

The fact that Mr Menzies was not satisfied with this response has caused Mr Perkins's advisers to write to me submitting further information. I now table their letter. The letter points out that Mr Perkins's refusal to disclose the precise source of the funds was based on legal advice, first, in relation to a dispute over Mr Menzies' jurisdiction in this matter and, secondly, on what was seen as an undue invasion of personal privacy.

Given the conclusions on this matter reported by Mr Menzies, however, and notwithstanding their continuing concerns about privacy, Mr Perkins and his legal advisers have now provided in their letter to me an unequivocal assurance from Mr Perkins that he paid for the taxis out of his own pocket. I accept that assurance. I state again that none of these various and extensive inquiries commissioned by the Government has found any evidence of misconduct or other actions by Mr Perkins of a serious kind warranting disciplinary action or censure.

It is time this House and this Parliament put those matters behind it and instead expressed its recognition of the substantial contribution Charles Perkins has made throughout his working life in the interests of advancing the cause of the Aboriginal people. Mr Perkins was at the vanguard of Aboriginal people to have a degree conferred on him from an Australian university, and while at university was President of Student Action for Aborigines. He became more widely known during the period from 1965 to 1969 when he was manager of the Foundation for Aboriginal Affairs.

He then moved into the government arena and for some 20 years has been applying all his energy, and drawing deeply on his commitment, to advance the cause of his people from his various positions within government. He has been a path-breaker for his people in working his way up through Public Service ranks in a competitive environment until he reached the top-the position from which he was best able to guide the development of policies and programs of value to Aboriginal people.

Charles Perkins believed that one of his most important roles was to keep in close touch with as many individual Aboriginal people, and as many Aboriginal communities, as he possibly could. Accordingly, he travelled extensively, and was able to bring to this Government and to previous governments an invaluable insight into the concerns and attitudes of his people. This is the context in which honourable members should view the reflections in these various inquiry reports on administrative shortcomings in organisational areas for which Mr Perkins has had responsibility.

Mr Deputy Speaker, Charles Perkins advised me some time ago that he wished to retire from the Public Service as soon as possible to pursue an alternative career, and has recently arranged to do so in the normal way through the Public Service Commissioner. I am advised his retirement will take effect from today. I express, on behalf of the Government, regret that his services as a full-time officer will be lost to the Government, and I hope honourable members will join me in wishing him well in his future career. For the Government's part, it will be actively seeking appropriate opportunities to engage Mr Perkins in appropriate part-time activity so that the wealth of his knowledge and experience is not totally lost to the Commonwealth.

In conclusion, I want to turn to the central issue in all of these inquiries-the quality of administration in Aboriginal affairs. I remind the House of the Government's approach set out in my statement of 11 April: that we should draw upon the lessons from these inquiries and look to the future, ensuring that mechanisms are put in place and support provided so that future administration is enhanced. Since then, steps have been taken in both the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to respond to findings in the earlier inquiry reports which were addressed in my statement.

In the case of the Aboriginal Development Commission, the adequacy of the Commission's procedures, systems and management controls has been audited by Price Waterhouse in the light of the findings in the earlier inquiries, and the recommendations from Price Waterhouse have now been implemented. A budget management committee and audit committee consisting of senior managers have been established in order to strengthen financial management and accountability. The Commission has also established a computer-based reporting system on program and project performance using monitoring indicators similar to those used in its reports to the Senate Estimates committee. Program and project performance reports are provided regularly to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In the case of the Department, substantial progress has been made in the development of program budgeting and in the provision of training for implementation of program budgeting and continues to be made in the administration of grant programs.

Ways in which aboriginalisation may be advanced are under discussion with unions, the Public Service Commission and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. New guidelines have been issued for official hospitality and for use of consultants; travel practices have been reviewed; and corrective action has been taken in regard to classification matters as recommended by the Department of Finance. Most importantly, priority has been given to staff development and training which will provide the specialist skills required for the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

I conclude by reminding honourable members of what I said in this House about ATSIC in my statement on 11 April. The Government's view then was and still is that this new Commission is the logical and appropriate next step for the advancement of both the great principles of self-management and ministerial accountability. Nothing in the earlier inquiry reports, nor in this final report from Mr Menzies, has shifted that belief on the part of the Government. Indeed, as I said in April, the inquiry reports give us encouragement that the proposed structure of ATSIC will be beneficial. As Prime Minister I fully support, and the Government as a whole fully supports, the initiatives the Minister has taken in proposing the creation of ATSIC.

As honourable members know, we have made some amendments to the ATSIC legislation in the light of these various inquiry reports and the report of the Senate select committee. Having done so, we are now firmly committed to proceeding with this legislation and establishing this body as quickly as possible. I hope this House and this Parliament will now accept that passage of this legislation, and establishment of ATSIC, is clearly in the best interests both of good government and of the necessary advancement of the administration of Aboriginal policy and programs for the benefit of the Aboriginal people of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In a letter to Mr A. C. C. Menzies dated 10 November 1988, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) outlined the nature of the inquiry into `certain aspects' of the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). At that time, the Auditor-General, the Public Service Commissioner and the Department of Finance were undertaking investigations into allegations which fell within their respective responsibilities. Mr Menzies' task was to inquire into specific allegations of illegal, corrupt or improper conduct or serious mismanagement of public funds or resources in light of the findings and recommendations of the previously mentioned investigations and audits, and any other matters which in his judgment warranted further examination.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Menzies issued an interim report in April 1989. At that time the Prime Minister made a statement to the House reporting the outcome of the inquiry so far and outlined the Government's proposal for a complete reorganisation of Aboriginal administration in the form of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). Mr Menzies' final report was delivered to the Prime Minister in June. It has been tabled today, and it is no doubt hoped that it will be lost in some of the pre-Budget build-up and hype. The Prime Minister has also foreshadowed a renewed push for the Government's ATSIC legislation. Debate on the ATSIC Bill was guillotined in this House in May and it is now, as I understand it, to be debated in the Senate during this Budget week.

The Opposition has been instrumental in pursuing the question of maladministration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs by the current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and by Ministers before him. That the Opposition had just cause is vindicated in the various reports issuing out of the many inquiries, including the Menzies inquiry, and the Prime Minister has admitted as much today. The report of the Auditor-General's special audit in particular illustrated the flawed nature of the Government's administration of Aboriginal affairs, and such maladministration is the fundamental reason why the government funding has not reached the very people most in need. Mr Menzies is also critical of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in his general observations. At page 6 he comments:
. . . a senior-level Task Force supported by seconded expert officers should be established to assist DAA to improve its administration.

The report clearly exonerates Charles Perkins. It recommends, as the Prime Minister has indicated in this House today, that no action should be taken against him-only that the terms of inquiries relating to him be brought to his attention. The Prime Minister now speaks in praise of Mr Perkins. His own Minister condemned Mr Perkins, and no wonder the Minister squirmed at the Prime Minister's words today. I have to say that, from the Opposition's point of view, the offer to employ or engage Mr Perkins in appropriate part time activities is welcomed by us. I have known and observed Charles Perkins over most of the period of my public life. We have seen one another from time to time over those many years at infrequent periods but I have had plenty of years to observe and develop a respect for him, and the respect that I hold him in is shared by honourable members on this side of the House. I am sure that he will be best able to judge his future uncoerced by any form of Government rhetoric, and I wish him well on behalf of the Opposition.

The Prime Minister today has also referred to improved guidelines, procedures and accountability for both the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal affairs. The Government has known of deficiencies in the administration of Aboriginal Affairs for years, and we could well ask why reforms were not undertaken some time ago. Now the Government proposes to undertake a massive and radical reorganisation of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio when its house is not yet in order. The Prime Minister's support for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as `the logical and appropriate next step for the advancement of both the great principles of self-management and ministerial accountability' is extraordinary. The ATSIC proposal has since its inception been fundamentally flawed and we on this side have been strong in our condemnation. I should advise the House of a number of the strong reasons for the coalition's continued opposition to the ATSIC proposal.

Firstly, the minority report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs found that the proposal for ATSIC was unjustified, unnecessary and culturally inappropriate and that it would operate to the detriment of Aborigines and lead to worse services and to less accountability to both Aborigines and Islanders and to all Australians. Secondly, the consultation process preceding the proposal for ATSIC has been inadequate. The majority of Aborigines do not identify with it. Thirdly, ATSIC regionalises and centralises control and therefore undermines traditional and local Aboriginal networks. In fact, the Minister will retain ultimate control of the Commission. Fourthly, it is a bureaucratic means of representation which takes no account of traditional Aboriginal processes. Fifthly, it is fundamentally flawed in that it seeks to incorporate representative and administrative processes in the same structure. Sixthly, it will add to waste and the duplication of programs at the three levels of government. And, seventhly, it will further isolate Aboriginal Australians in what would virtually be a black parliament.

Despite the Prime Minister's tabling of the Menzies report today and hoping that its findings will not undermine ATSIC, the coalition, as you will gather from these objections, Mr Deputy Speaker, will continue its strong opposition to ATSIC. The Government must get its administration of Aboriginal affairs in order before indulging in ideologically motivated schemes which do not address the real health, education and housing needs of our Aboriginal people and which could further marginalise their position as Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I start by saying that the Opposition is very pleased to be back in the Parliament today and very pleased to have the Government clearly in its sights. Tonight the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will deliver his seventh-and undoubtedly his last-Budget. SPEECH.PARA: There are a few sops for the elderly, and they are not going to be conned by that. I simply say that, for all the hot air coming from this Government-and there will be lots of it tonight, and tomorrow particularly-everybody knows that Australia has not been run very well in recent years. I do not need some opinion poll to substantiate the obvious, but I noted yesterday a poll to the effect that the community sentiment about this country's economic health was bleak: nearly 50 per cent of voters regarded the economy as poor and only 11 per cent considered economic conditions good or very good. One does not need to be an economist to see some of the problems that have brought people to make those sorts of conclusions.

I want to put on the table today seven of the deadly sins, if you like, of Labor's economic management. Firstly, wages: wages are very interesting, because this Government has very strong claims about wages. If we look at the detail, we see that the fact is that we have been running one of the worst wages policies of any country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. We have a system whereby we keep paying ourselves increases much higher than those of our competitors. One of the things that really undermine the competitiveness of this economy is, in fact, our wage structure and wage policy.

That is followed up by the other side of that coin, that is, very high inflation. I mention that because, in fact, inflation higher than our wages growth brings me to my third sin, that is, Labor's low wage policy. One of the things I really resent about this Government is that it tells everybody else that they ought to pull in their belts but it never actually bothers to pull in its own belt. Those opposite-and they are proud of it-say to people, `We have done a great job. We have encouraged the whole community to tighten their belts'. When one thinks about that, it is a pretty odd thing to say really, because the bottom line of that is, `We have done really well because we have encouraged everybody to actually accept a lower standard of living'. It is a low wage policy.

The fourth deadly sin is a continuing balance of payments problem-over $17 billion in the last year, quite contrary to all the projections made by the Treasurer last year. The fifth deadly sin, I say, is the way in which we run industrial relations in this country. Again, we hear a lot of hot air from this Government about the level of strikes and industrial disputes in this country. Have a look at the figures, because the fact is that, when it comes to industrial relations, we have a record which is appalling. I do not say that lightly. Look at our international competitors and see how many days they lose as a result of strikes and industrial disputes. Look at West Germany. Our record is something like 50 times higher than West Germany's. Honourable members will not be surprised. Look at the Japanese economy. Our figure is something like 24 times higher than that country's. Let us look at the United Kingdom. The Labor Party loves to say, `That Margaret Thatcher, she is a terrible woman; she is a confrontationist'. But our industrial record in this country is 2 1/2 times worse than the industrial relations record in the United Kingdom.

The sixth area, I say, is productivity. `Productivity' is an economics jargon word, but it is a pretty simple one which I think most people understand. It is a measure of how efficiently we run this country. It is inputs over outputs. Again, if one looks at the figures on productivity, one sees that our record is not a good one. I call it the yawning productivity gap. In this country our productivity levels are actually on the decline; they are actually falling. If one compares that with how other countries are doing, one sees that their productivity figures are actually on the increase. We are going down; they are going up. If honourable members want to know why this country is lacking competitiveness and why we are having trouble selling our goods in the markets of the world, the fact is that we are not running our businesses as efficiently as we ought to. That yawning productivity gap tells a considerable story about our economic management.

The seventh deadly sin that I put on the table today is the one that really sums everything up, and that is this country's international debt. We are told about the tremendous abilities of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-what economic whiz kids they are and what a great job they have done for seven years-but let us look at the figures. When they came to office this country had a debt-it had taken us 190-odd years to get to it-of about $23 billion. They reckon that that was a lot of money. They say, `Blame it all on the last Government', but under their economic management our debt has gone from $23 billion to $103 billion. Eighty billion dollars of that debt is their business. It is the result of their economic management and they ought to be pinned with the responsibility for it.

Every month we buy, as a nation, more from overseas than we are capable of selling; so every month we increase the debt. The Government's answer is that because our economy is growing too fast we must tighten our belts and spend less. That is its only solution. So it jacks up interest rates deliberately so as to stop families, young people and businesses from spending; in fact, it puts a choker on the whole economy. It is just a joke for the Prime Minister to come in here and talk about what he is going to do by way of relief for young home buyers when that is his policy. It is like playing Australian rules and a bloke clocks you from behind, breaks your leg, and says, as he carries you off on a stretcher, `She'll be right, mate. I'll buy you the crutches'. If it was Bob Hawke he would say, `And vote for me as well'.

The fact is that it is the Government's policies that have given us high interest rates. The Government has some choices but it cares not to take them. Labor's policy, therefore, is that if we do well, if the economy booms, we have to put on the brakes. That is a poverty trap of macro proportions. It is the ultimate stop-start approach. The Treasurer is very keen on the analogy that he will move us from the fast lane into the middle lane. The truth is that his policy is quite different from that. In most races one goes round and heads towards the finish, perhaps stopping once in the pit stops for a fuel pickup. Under the Treasurer's policy one goes into the pit stops after every lap. Whenever this economy starts to get going and get a head of steam, Labor's policy says, `We can't do any more, we can't grow, we have to put a stop to it'. That is a very negative view about the future prospects of this country. That is where the differences between the way in which the Labor Party runs the economy and the way in which we would run the economy are very great and considerable. The Labor Party takes a negative view. We say in response that there is a much better way of running this country than has been the case in recent years. We reject the defeatist policy that keeping interest rates high is the only thing that can be done.

I have identified some of the ills and will now look at some of the prescriptions. Looking at the prescriptions, the good news is that there are literally hundreds of thousands of things that we, as a community, could do to pick up this economy, to pay off our debts and to move forward without the sort of millstone around our grandchildren's necks that will be the legacy of this Government. The one thing that Labor fears the most is that the people in the electorate, the people who ultimately decide these issues, will cotton on to the simple message that there is a much better way of running this economy than what we have had from the Labor Party.

I have brought in here a few of the plans and policies. We have policies coming out of our ears. We have plans, schemes, new ideas, and initiatives-good things to do to start turning around this economy. It is a pretty thick list. If the Prime Minister stood up on it he would be up to the shoulder of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). Chapter 1 deals with industrial relations. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) is at the table. The fact is that there is much that we can do. This area is significant because it is not just about how we run our businesses. Having industrial relations policy and doing things better are things we can do in virtually every institution in the country. I am the shadow Minister for education. Our industrial relations proposals for universities are a great idea. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is attacking them; he wants to run higher education from Canberra. If we had our industrial relations practice and policy put into place that would put a stop to a lot of that right from the start. We can have better industrial relations in our schools. We have a plan for that.

My colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) is going to talk about what we could do with the waterfront if we had better industrial relations. The waterfront is costing us $850m a year. That is a conservative estimate. It has absolutely ruined our reputation as a reliable supplier, and the frustrating thing is that the answers are obvious. We have printed them in black and white. We have fine print by the load. The fact is that even the Government itself has acknowledged, on privatisation and some of these other issues, that there is a better way of doing things than we have now.

Let us take industrial relations. We say that one of the first things we ought to do in industrial relations is to encourage a different approach to the way in which we conduct the whole thing. At the moment if there is a problem in industrial relations the first thing people do if they are in a union is pick up the phone and ring the union representative. If they are employers, the first thing they do is pick up the phone and ring the employer organisation. If those two cannot get together, they bring in the umpire. The first thing we ought to do in industrial relations is to encourage people to talk one to another. So one of the ideas we have is share ownership. I think that is a great idea to encourage people, to say to them, `Look, you have a stake in this business and, through having a stake in your business-your enterprise-you have a stake in the future of this country'. The list of good ideas that we have to turn this country round is a long one. Let me conclude by saying that this is a good country; we have a good people; we have a bright future; but in recent years we have not been running this country as well as we should. It is time for a change, and it is time for the community out there to grasp these good ideas, to support them and to criticise this Government for its failure to adopt some of the good ideas that would address our basic problems.
