The key to change on the waterfront is to open up the whole industry to competition. The gradualist approach, which has been adopted in the past, has failed to solve the fundamental problems on the waterfront. There are three dimensions to introducing competition on the waterfront. First, greater competition between ports should be encouraged. This should include putting individual ports under their own port authorities. Port authorities should primarily be run by users and should have explicitly commercial charters. Secondly, there should be greater competition within ports between companies providing services such as stevedoring and towage. All port services should be provided following an explicit tendering process. Contracts should be for relatively short fixed terms.

The third part is that competition should be introduced into the labour market. This entails a number of things. Firstly, employers should have the normal freedom to hire and fire employees. That is something that is not presently available on the waterfront today. Secondly, the Federal and port coordinating committees should be abolished. There should be no third party interference in manning levels. Individual companies should be free to determine how many employees, including casuals, they require. Employers should not be required to recruit labour from the Waterside Workers Federation register. There should be no obligation on employers to recruit labour in the name of rejuvenation beyond what they deem commercially appropriate. There should be no externally imposed obligations on training. Levy arrangements should be terminated. Employers and employees should be free to negotiate directly terms and conditions of their own employment, and there should be changes to legislation governing union coverage to permit employers to negotiate with unions not traditionally represented on the waterfront. There should be legislative changes in order to enforce all of those things.

What the Opposition is all about in its package of policies for the waterfront, one of which I have just referred to, is to make this country more productive and more competitive. What we see today, with the Government's refusal to allow the Wheat Board to implement its reforms, is hypocrisy of the greatest order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —That really was an extraordinary speech. It did not have much to do with the subject of the matter of public importance, which is supposed to be about industrial relations. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) was apparently recycling a speech on waterfront reform that he had given in the earlier part of the year in an earlier sitting of the House. It was strange to hear him talking about a subject that really had nothing to do with the subject of the matter of public importance at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposer of the matter, in his vacuous and rather bland speech, made some extraordinary comments. The one that leapt out at me, I must say, was that wages were increasing too fast and that wages were too low. He seemed to want to have it both ways. It was an extraordinary speech. This is really an astonishing matter of public importance, if we take it as it is written, because at the very same time that the Government, employers, unions and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission are cooperating on the introduction of major reform of the whole industrial relations system, award restructuring, the Opposition is proposing to destroy that reform.

Those opposite really do not seem to have been watching what is going on at all. They appear to be arguing that wages would increase more slowly in the kind of deregulated system that they are advocating; but their view ignores history and it is, of course, simplistic and doctrinaire. On the worst recent occasion when the centralised wage fixing system broke down, 1981-82, there was a period of inflationary wage growth which was quickly followed by escalating unemployment as a result of the loss of jobs. The application of the kinds of simplistic competitive models of the labour market which they are proposing neglects the fact that complex human beings are involved who have a strong sense of justice about comparative wage levels, and that unions are performing a centrally important job in restraining exploitation and in ensuring the sharing of the benefits of increasing productivity.

A wise incomes policy, as distinct from the very superficial one that the Opposition is advocating, must take account of all the realities, as well as desired outcomes. The accord, which has been in place for the past nearly seven years, draws unions, businesses and other community groups into consultation with government to reach broad agreement about the distributional questions which underlie inflation. This discussion and persuasion is more humane than the brutality of the Fraser years of bludgeoning the economy into submission through high unemployment, large numbers of bankruptcies, and bitter labour disputes.

We have heard the Minister describe the successes of the voluntary, comprehensive and equitable prices and income policy which we have had in the last six or seven years. He has talked about the reduction in the number of industrial disputes. He did not proclaim that as strongly as he might have. In 1981 there were 4,200 days lost per 1,000 workers. In recent years, that has been down to just over 1,000 days per 1,000 workers each year, which is just about a quarter of the level it was at in 1981. Of course, the principal achievement of the accord has been that through the stable, steady industrial relations system, and the wages that have flowed from it, we have had a growth in employment of about 1 1/2 million. The Minister made that point very strongly and it is the centrally important achievement of the prices and incomes policy.

It is difficult to understand why Opposition members should continue to raise the question of an enterprise-based approach to industrial relations. Which planet have they been on during the last two years? In that time, huge strides have been made through the accord to accommodate greater enterprise flexibility in the centralised wages system while ensuring economically responsible wage outcomes. Let me remind the House what those developments have been. In early 1987, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as it then was switched the emphasis of the wage-fixing system away from indexed across-the-board increases to productivity-based wage rises at enterprise level. That was the two-tiered system.

This new system was a breakthrough but it was interpreted in many companies as a narrow cost cutting approach rather than a long term efficiency approach. That led to the three wage decisions of the past 12 months which put in place the structural efficiency principle and the framework for award restructuring. It is far more constructive today to discuss the qualities and benefits of the new system than to waste any further time on the doctrinaire and quite superficial alternative being proposed by the Opposition; and we did not get much of the alternative in the presentation of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith).

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote your speech?

—I wrote it myself and I believe it is true. Award restructuring implies nothing less than the complete overhaul of Australia's antiquated system of industrial awards and agreements. It has now been endorsed and developed as a focus for wage determination and labour market reform in a series of Industrial Relations Commission decisions beginning in August last year. In the first place, the new structural efficiency principle has been developed to go beyond the narrow costs offsets approach of the two tiered system. This encompasses a number of issues which are being addressed in negotiations on new awards, including the recently agreed metal and engineering industry award. These issues do not simply require change on the part of the work force. They place a clear responsibility on employers to act as well. These principles include the reduction of outmoded job classifications to a smaller number of skill levels. The Opposition could not possibly disagree with that proposal and I am delighted to see the agreement of unions and business to that kind of principle.

SPEECH.PARA: The principles also include development of new career structures with opportunities for personal advancement. They include the provision of high quality training with recognised standards and accreditation. It is impossible to see in the Opposition's approach to industrial relations how it provides an incentive for training, yet training is the necessary condition for building up productivity. They involve expanded opportunities for women and the removal of discrimination in awards and procedures for sharing inform- ation and consulting workers on new technology, training and work organisation. The framework for change at enterprise level is to be established by the award negotiations themselves and we see they are under way at present. Trade unions are required to pursue this fundamental review of their awards together with employer bodies. Progress is taking place in a structured, broadly based way. An environment is being created for the translation of the new awards into action, not just in a handful of go-ahead companies, and there are plenty of those, but in the vast majority of enterprises throughout Australia.
Perhaps the most significant feature of award restructuring is its restoration of the principles of equity and fairness to centre stage.

This will be achieved by the new matrix of relationships between key award rates proposed in the Australian Council of Trade Unions blueprint and accepted in principle by the Industrial Relations Commission in its May decision, and by the assessing of new minimum rates. Not only will this dramatic step bring in a fairer wage system, but it will also ensure greater stability through what we must all fervently hope will be an elimination of destructive leap-frogging. Let me say that I regard the series of national wage decisions over the past year as the most revolutionary since the 1907 Harvester judgment established a basic wage. Award restructuring provides an historic opportunity to strengthen the foundations of the accord by translating the principles of involvement and fairness into action at the workplace.

The Opposition's motion is really fantasy. It simply applies ideological categories to an area of policy about which it appears to know next to nothing. Its views are outdated. They take no account of the realities of the workplace. Their proposals will allow exploitation; they are fundamentally unfair. Members of the Opposition have not even worked out the details in the same way as they do not seem to have worked out the details of their tax or any other policy. Their proposals, in so far as they can be discerned, involve destroying an amazingly effective system in a complex and fragile situation which could lead to breakdown, disorder and chaos. Australia is far better to stick with what it knows. It is far better to rely on the workable than to be tempted by an illusion. The House and all Australians should wholeheartedly reject the Opposition's confused and misguided proposal.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 contains about 20 pages of amendments to several Acts of the Parliament for which the Attorney-General is responsible. I think it is fair to say that most of the proposed amendments require no comment at all. Some of them are machinery provisions. Other provisions are of more substance and yet, despite that, are not contentious. I would simply draw attention to a few matters that fall under four headings because they seem to deserve particular attention.

SPEECH.PARA: The first relates to what might be described as telephone offences. We find in the Bill that two new offences will be created. We support this proposal. The two new offences that will be created will be, first of all, offences relating to the unauthorised call switching devices that are used apparently by illegal bookmakers. I am not familiar with their use of such devices, but I am informed of it and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has given us the factual basis for this change to the law. I am prepared to accept that what he says is true. Apparently, unauthorised call switching devices are in use. They are used by illegal bookmakers and others to divert telephone calls in the course of conducting their businesses-if that is the appropriate word-the object of that exercise being to prevent detection. It is appropriate that the use of such devices be an offence. Therefore, we support the Government's proposal to make it an offence.

The second offence being created under this heading is with respect to the actual equipment by means of which illegal telephone interceptions are effected. The change to the law will in effect outlaw the actual equipment itself. We regard those as being two changes to the law which, I am sure, will contribute to the law enforcement and law detection process.

The second area relates to telephone interceptions. The Bill will allow designated technical officers to give technical assistance when telephone interceptions are being carried out. The second reading speech refers to the people concerned as `civilian technicians'. The Bill itself uses some other expression. Because of the use of the other expression-`a designated technical officer'-it would seem to be the objective that the officers will not be police officers themselves, but rather civilians who provide the support staff for the Australian Federal Police. The proposal is to allow these designated technical officers employed by the Australian Federal Police to give technical assistance when telephone interceptions are being carried out. There are only two things to say about that. The first is that we would support the proposed change to the law on the basis that there is a need for those persons to assist the police in the course of conducting their lawful telephone interception activities. One can understand why this technical assistance is needed and it is appropriate that the law should provide for it.

We believe, however, that the clause is too wide. As I have said, undoubtedly there is a need for particular persons to be authorised to carry out this activity, but the Bill goes further than that. The Bill allows classes of persons to be designated technical officers for the purpose of this new provision. We believe that it is too wide. It is one thing to give this authority to individuals; it is another thing entirely to give a broad general authority to classes of persons. I presume the classes would be described by reference to their grading, their grouping or their category of employment. We would not be designating who they are. We believe that that goes too far. It should be remembered in considering this issue that they are given quite extensive powers.

If one looks at clause 44 (5) one finds that when authorised these people will be able, amongst other things, to engage in the following activities: first of all, the installation of equipment which is going to be used to intercept telephone calls. So they are going to be able to install the equipment itself. Secondly, and most importantly, they are going to be able to use it. They will be engaged in the maintenance, testing or use of the equipment. So, in fact, they are going to be using telephone interception equipment. No light burden is being put upon them; no light authority or power is being given to them. What we say is that if it is necessary to have such persons engage in this assistance-and we accept that it is-they should be designated by some more precise terms and not by terms which are as wide as those used in the Bill, namely, classes of persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you define them?
—We will be proposing an amendment and in the course of discussing the amendment I will answer the honourable member for McEwen's question.

SPEECH.PARA: The third matter I wish to raise relates to the Privacy Act which honourable members will recall we passed last year. The purpose of the amendment that the Government is proposing is to have officers of the Ombudsman around Australia authorised to receive and handle privacy complaints on behalf of the Privacy Commissioner. One may wonder why that is necessary. We are given the answer to that by the Bill and by the Attorney-General's second reading speech, the answer being that it will enable the Privacy Commissioner to have an Australia-wide presence. I understand from a letter I have received from the Attorney-General that the Government will be moving an amendment to tighten this up and I can see that the proposed amendment is an improvement.

With respect, I think there are still some difficulties. The proposed amendment to the Bill which will limit this power to those who have received an express delegation from the Privacy Commissioner may go part way towards resolving the problems. But it may be that in the course of the debate here today some of the potential problems in the use of this new procedure will be further elaborated on. However, at this stage we can simply make the point that the purpose is apparently to provide a sort of shopfront presence for the Privacy Commissioner throughout the whole of Australia. One can do that by two means: one can set up an office in each capital city and presumably each provincial city so that everyone can get to the Privacy Commissioner; or, alternatively, one can take some path such as the path proposed by the Government, namely, to allow the officers of the Ombudsman to receive on behalf of the Privacy Commissioner complaints under the Privacy Act and to handle them. It may be that when the Attorney-General is proposing his amendment he will tell us a little more about how this is going to operate.

The fourth and final area to which I wish to draw attention is an amendment to the Evidence Act relating to evidence which is prejudicial to security. That Act allows evidence taken-I am abbreviating the system here, of course-in Australian courts to be used in proceedings in foreign courts. Here again, it is proposed to make an amendment. In this case the amendment will propose that the Attorney-General may make an order prohibiting the production of documents or the giving of evidence or information if that evidence would prejudice Australia's security. It is proposed, therefore, that if evidence is going to be given which would prejudice Australia's security, the Attorney-General may make an order prohibiting the giving of that evidence or the production of those documents, presumably in accordance with the principle that the national security overrides all. We would support that principle.

The Bill goes on to tell us that the Federal Court of Australia may enforce compliance with the order. It may be that some would argue that the Court itself should make the order and not just enforce it, which is what the Bill does. However, we would support the amendment as it stands because, as I have already indicated, matters of national security really should be left to the Government to determine. It is up to the Government to make right decisions on these matters. Of course, there is a price to pay if the Government does not make the right decisions, which on occasions it does not.

Finally, I think it is worthwhile referring in passing to the new Independent Commission Against Corruption which gets a mention in this Bill. That body is joining the league of approved bodies on whose behalf telephone interceptions may be conducted. The Bill will allow this New South Wales body to be one such body. It is a body to which intercepted information may be communicated. As with all other similar bodies set up in the fight against corruption and major crime, we trust that giving this not inconsiderable power and right to the new Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales will result in some achievements being realised. We want some results. We are giving a considerable power to this body and one hopes that one will see the results from the use of this and its other very extensive powers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) that the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales is indeed achieving results. One may recall, of course, that the Greiner Liberal Government set up that body to trap the Labor Party. It was going to be one of those wonderful political arms of liberalism, of conservatism, to be used as a political weapon against its opponent, the Labor Party. Indeed, what has been the result? We are getting the National Party-Mr Murray and his cronies. We are seeing an extension of what occurred in Queensland flowing down into New South Wales. This is one of those wonderful weapons that politicians sometimes come up with, that they think will be a wonderful thing for themselves and which turns around and bites them on the ankle. I hope that many more conservatives in New South Wales get bitten on the ankle by this beast. I am pleased in fact that the Opposition does not object to the extension of powers to the Independent Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say, Mr Deputy Speaker, with due respect to the honourable member for Menzies, whom I would not put in this individual category, that in general terms the conservatives in this place are, of course, soft on crime. They are the people who historically have been absolutely supportive of the sorts of corruption which, when we took office, had become endemic in this country. One only has to go back to the 1980s, only a couple of years ago, when a man who was called, from memory, Johannes Bjelke-Petersen had been the Premier of Queensland for a number of years. I recall that when we raised matters in this House that dared suggest that Johannes Bjelke-Petersen was anything but a fine, upright, moral man we were greeted with hoots of derision from the conservatives opposite. In fact, any suggestion by members of this House that corruption was rampant in the northern State under conservative rule was treated most violently. Indeed, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the famous head kicker of the House, was one of those who did more violent gyrations in this place when there were attacks on the honourable gentleman from the north. We all know what is the Bible of conservative government in this country. It has been printed; it is a large book. This copy has a red cover. Of course, the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct-the Fitzgerald report-is now the ultimate Bible of conservative government in Australia.

Now we know that probably the same thing will flow from New South Wales-that bribery and corruption follow when those who see power as a means to an end do get government and do control office. The suggestions coming from New South Wales are that Mr Murray and his cohorts are more than anxious to assist their friends in development. The evidence coming out of New South Wales is similar to that from Queensland under the conservatives there.

Mr Deputy Speaker, crime knows no boundaries and regrettably from my point of view-I have made this comment before-I thought the Fitzgerald inquiry frankly failed in its ambit. It did not, unfortunately, cover organised crime. It did not reveal and trace the movements of crime from Queensland into New South Wales. Organised crime, as I said, knows no boundaries. The inquiry did not pursue it and did not chase the money trail into the drug rackets of Queensland.

When I listened to and read the evidence of some of the people who appeared before Fitzgerald, all suggesting that their ill-gotten gains came from simple governmental corruption or prostitution-and they all ran a million miles away from any suggestion of drugs-my hair prickled, quite frankly, because I do not believe it. We tend to forget the Costigan inquiry. We tend to forget that that royal commission pointed at Queensland as being the home of drug money. Noosa was identified by Costigan as being the place where the ill-gotten gains of the major drug dealers ended up going mostly. There was not a mention of that in the Fitzgerald inquiry. I was invited on several programs as Chairman of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority to make comments on Fitzgerald. But when I gave those viewpoints to the people from the various channels before going on the program, they all ran away from them. They did not want such comments at that time about Fitzgerald.

The second thing I found sad about the Fitzgerald inquiry was that people were not named. What is the use of having a royal commission with privilege unless you point the bone? And the bone was not pointed by Fitzgerald clearly enough, often enough and obviously enough. In fact, it was the only royal commission in Australia that we can think of where the royal commissioner concerned did not point the bone.

The last thing I was disappointed with and which I believe is worth criticising is that we know where corruption comes from in Queensland. It comes from the Cabinet, from within the Cabinet, from around the Cabinet and Sir Robert Sparkes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is all very interesting and we have seen it on television and read it in the newspapers. The only thing one can say with certainty about it is that it does not have anything to do with this Bill whatsoever. I did not raise any point of order when the honourable member was referring to the New South Wales commission because it is referred to in the Bill. But the matters that he has been traversing now for some minutes really are completely irrelevant to any section of this Bill and he should be asked to confine himself to perhaps less interesting but nevertheless more relevant matters.

—I have been listening carefully to the remarks of the honourable member for McEwen and particularly to questions of drugs and crime as they are relevant to the legislation. I think the member largely is within the requirements of the debate. However, I would ask him to focus specifically upon some of the elements of the legislation.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker. Perhaps I would refer my honourable colleague to part 12 of the amendments here. They go to amendments to the State and Territorial Laws and Records Recognition Act which concerns the administration of government and of votes and proceedings of State parliaments. These are the very things which Fitzgerald homed in on. So in that sense, of course, Fitzgerald is very relevant to this Bill because we are by this amendment Bill amending the votes and proceedings of State parliaments and inserting new sections. I would have thought that anyone who is concerned with government would indeed go to Fitzgerald to see what he has to say about what can go wrong with government.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member claims that this legislation somehow determines the proceedings of State parliaments in a specific way. If that is relevant, he ought to be required to point out exactly where it is relevant.
—Order! I call the honourable member for McEwen.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Perhaps the honourable member for Flinders could read clauses 33, 36 and 38. I think it is important that when we talk about law and justice at the Federal level we take note of what occurs in State parliaments and of matters of corruption. The fact that members of the Opposition do not want to debate these matters in this House proves again their softness, their lack of care. Who introduced the Proceeds of Crime Bill, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, the Telecommunications (Interception) Bill? Which has been the most aggressive parliament in Australia's history in regard to its attack on organised crime? Who established the National Crime Authority? When we get around to company law, trying to bring to justice for their misdeeds some company directors, it is the conservatives who oppose the necessary regulations and controls. When we try to get a national law on companies, who opposes it? It is the conservatives. They are the soft people on crime. They are soft on regulation to prevent the misuse of power by government, by companies and in criminal areas. When we introduce these measures they oppose them.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality that Mr Fitzgerald discloses so clearly is that, by themselves, convention and tradition do not prevent the creation of the hydra-headed monster of organised crime and corruption. The prevention of organised crime requires the sort of people who cannot be bought. It requires the sort of people who believe that morality and ethics stand above pocket. It requires political parties that believe that morality and ethics in politics stand above campaign funds. One thing Fitzgerald clearly demonstrated was that one can buy a political party lock, stock and barrel, and it can be headed by Sir Robert Sparkes who can manipulate a political system from outside a parliament. It can be bought by delivering brown paper packages full of cash to the office of a Premier of a State which then goes somewhere into a company called Kaldeal. It can be manipulated by political favours, by making money payments to a Premier. Australians have not yet woken up to the monster that is in Queensland. I do not think Australians are quite clear about just how corruption can extend right through a system, from police to education to unions--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Victoria?

—I am happy that someone has mentioned Victoria. I have a good history in Victoria. I served in the police force there for years. I went through the Mr X inquiry, the Beech inquiry, the Ford inquiry-Victoria has had them, years ago. We had corruption in Victoria and we cleaned it out.
—You have not had a look at Victoria Incorporated, have you?
—We cleaned it out under a Labor government.
—Have a look at the corruption in government now.

—There is no problem about that. The honourable member can talk to me about Victoria any time he likes and I will tell him what we did about organised crime down there. We cleaned it right out. I again come back to the matters raised by Mr Fitzgerald. Fitzgerald says in his report that he has only scratched the surface of Queensland. He says that he did not have time to get into the depth of corruption in Queensland. Yet the people who presided over this still have their hands in the bickie tin; they still have the capacity to appoint the people to make the inquiries for them under terms of reference which they, the people with their hands in the bickie tin, dictate. That is the fault of Fitzgerald; that is the wrongness of the Fitzgerald report. The people who are responsible are still in a position to dictate the terms of any reference, to appoint the people, and in fact to do nothing about the real problems in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Menzies quite properly pointed out that this is an omnibus Bill; and it does cover many aspects. As I said earlier, one thing that it again clearly shows to Australians is that this Government is determined to do all in its power to attack crime and to do all in its power to ensure that the machinery of government, the machinery of police, and the machinery of justice are geared up to operate, wherever possible, to strike down organised crime.

I have said in the past, and I say again, that I have some concerns about telephone communications interception. It is, as the honourable member for Menzies said, a powerful weapon that impedes the individual rights of people. When the honourable member spoke he drew my attention to clause 44, and I must confess that I then read the Bill, because I respect the views of the honourable gentleman. Now that I have had a good look at it-and I have not yet heard the terms of the amendment-I am not sure whether he has got it right.

In order to be a designated technical officer under clause 44 or under section 55 of the principal Act, the person must be a member of the staff referred to in section 16 of the Australian Federal Police Act. A person can become a designated officer only with the approval in writing of the Commissioner of Police. There are two things there: firstly, the person must be a member of staff referred to in section 16 of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 and, secondly, he or she must be approved in writing by a commissioner of police to be a person of the class who can be a designated technical officer. Is the honourable member suggesting that that creates a wide class of person or a class of person who may not be subjected to control, who may not be subjected to control of a police commissioner, who may not be subjected to secrecy, or who may not be subjected to discipline? I asked, by way of interjection: `How would you describe them?'. The honourable member suggested that in his amendment he would, in fact, give some detail of that.

I will listen with interest because, as I said, I do respect the honourable gentleman's views. For many years he was my Federal member of parliament-mind you, I voted consistently against him; nevertheless, he kept winning-and he is a man I respect and a man of principle. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could be forgiven for being amused by the reference of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) to events in Queensland, particularly the creation of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and its aftermath. He referred disparagingly to the fact that the Government up there may set terms of reference and thereby control any future inquiry that may or may not be required. What he failed to do was give credit to Premier Ahern for, firstly, creating the Fitzgerald inquiry and, secondly, giving the inquirer the necessary resources to do the job and expose to the view of the public those matters which appear to be so wrong in the State of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable gentleman were sincere in his expressed concern, I would have expected him to say that probably we could be doing similar things in the States of Western Australia and Victoria, where maybe there is not the type of corruption to which he has referred in Queensland, which was examined by Fitzgerald, but where a form of corruption in the conduct and process of government is taking place and has occurred without parallel and on a massive scale not experienced in this country before. There is more than one form of corruption. I notice that in his usual involved fashion the honourable member for McEwen is not in his seat and probably is not listening. If he were sincere he would like to see that process extended to not only New South Wales, as the Premier, Mr Greiner, has done, but also those States where there is more than casual evidence of a corruption of the process of government which warrants a thorough inquiry under terms of reference at least as generous as those that Premier Ahern gave to Fitzgerald.

Included in this omnibus Bill is a proposal to amend the Privacy Act 1988. Given the Government's record with inaccurately drafted or thought through legislation, it comes as no great surprise that a fundamental change is now required to legislation passed as recently as last year. That law established the office of Privacy Commissioner within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) effective from January 1989. It now seems that the Government deems it necessary for the staff of the Commonwealth Ombudsman to be the delegates of the Privacy Commissioner in certain circumstances. Complaints to the Privacy Commissioner are intended to be referable to the Ombudsman's staff. So too will it be possible to get the assistance of the Ombudsman's staff to assist a person formulating a complaint about an act or practice which could be an infringement of an individual's privacy and in breach of the principal Act. Although it is a stated intention that delegation may be authorised in those parts of Australia where there is no office of the HREOC, it appears that there will be nothing to prevent the Privacy Commissioner delegating, regardless of the existence of an office of the HREOC. That may not be all that objectionable, but it is, if not unintended, an unstated consequence of what is proposed.

The amendments go further than I have so far indicated in at least one important respect. Section 99 of the principal Act is to be changed. Before amendment, as it presently stands, section 99 enables the Commissioner to delegate to a member of the HREOC any powers given under the Act with one exception of prime importance. The amendment now intended will expose the Ombudsman's staff to the same delegated duties as already attach to the staff of the HREOC. In practical terms, all this means is that the Privacy Commissioner may in future draw on the resources of both the HREOC and the Ombudsman, whereas at the moment that access to staff is limited to the HREOC. The proposed changes beg the question: Does the Privacy Commissioner have, or have the prospect of getting, sufficient resources to do his important work? It would seem not. If not, can the Government be said to have a commitment to the office it created by legislation only last year? Again, it would seem not. Remember if you will, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Government was brought screaming, as it were, to the point where it had to legislate to protect the privacy of individuals following the revelation of some notorious examples of abuses by both government agencies and others. Such protection was also a precondition demanded by the coalition before acceptance of the then proposed tax file numbers legislation. In fact, it is probably fair to say that tax file number legislation would not have been passed by the Parliament if concurrent privacy laws-those privacy laws embodied in the principal Act-were not also in place.

That brings me back to my earlier reference to the amendment proposed to section 99 in the principal Act, the Privacy Act 1988. I have already pointed out that there was one exception to the catch-all delegation proposal. That exception stipulated exclusion, and continues to exclude, the possibility of delegation to anyone of the duties of the Privacy Commissioner concerning either the issue of the tax file number guidelines or determinations under section 52 of the principal Act. My colleague the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) will be pleased to know that. He will be pleased because he has an outstanding reference before the Privacy Commissioner. Interestingly, he referred the same matter to the Ombudsman, the same officeholder whose staff may in future be coopted to help the Commissioner.

The matter referred to the Privacy Commissioner by the honourable member for Moreton concerned the very questionable activities of the Statistician and his conduct of the notorious household expenditure survey. That very recent experience raises some interesting possibilities if these amendments are passed. Whereas it has been possible to refer to each of the Ombudsman and the Privacy Commissioner the same matter, albeit with different emphasis and even objectives, that might be practical in future. Think of the possibilities. With the passage of these amendments we could see a classic case of conflict of interest between the personnel of the office of the Ombudsman and those of the Privacy Commissioner. There appears to be nothing in the Act as it is to be amended which will prevent the Privacy Commissioner delegating to staff of the Ombudsman a responsibility to act in a matter referred to each. In such a case, can the same staff be involved without compromising the intentions and provisions of separate legislation, or will reference to one preclude the same matter being referred to the other despite reasons being different? Only one thing is certain: the explanations given for these amendments do not provide the answer.

Given a working relationship to be established between the offices of the Privacy Commissioner and the Ombudsman, one could abandon for all time any hope that reference to one about conduct or a possible breach by the other would be worth while. Future allegations to the Ombudsman about a breach of duty by the Privacy Commissioner's staff would not be seen-I emphasise the word `seen'-to afford the prospect of justice because there is an actual, potential or perceived conflict of interest. It might even transpire in some cases that a particular reference to the Ombudsman against the Commissioner could be similar to or the same as one the Commissioner has already delegated to the Ombudsman. Then again, the converse could arise. There could be a claim that the Ombudsman has breached the Privacy Act. These are very real possibilities. It is not going too far to speculate that such scenarios are inevitable given this Government's unparalleled record for intrusion into the everday affairs of individuals. It is bad enough that the office of the Privacy Commissioner is a mere appendage to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. That fact begs the question as to how he will handle an allegation of a breach of the Privacy Act against the HREOC. Having handled one, will his involvement be objective? Will any ensuing findings be seen to be those of an independent arbiter? I doubt it. Who would not doubt it?

Let us look at another possibility that can arise under the principal Act as it now stands. Section 36 provides that an individual may complain to the Privacy Commissioner about an act or practice that may be an interference with his or her privacy and that staff of the HREOC are required to assist that person in formulating the complaint. What is to happen if that complaint is against the HREOC? There is plenty of scope in the work of the HREOC for one to arise. Is it to prepare the case against itself? Remembering that the Privacy Commissioner and his office are an integral part of the HREOC, will he launch himself into the fray without fear or favour? Even if he does with complete conviction, objectivity and abandon, will any outcome or findings not favourable to the complainant be taken seriously? The questions answer themselves. It is equally obvious that both the offices of the Ombudsman and the Privacy Commissioner will be diminished by this amendment.

A further aspect should be canvassed. It is also about the Privacy Commissioner's proposed ability to delegate his responsibilities to the Commonwealth Ombudsman in centres where there is no office of the HREOC. To be able to do so effectively either there has to be an excess of capacity in the particular office of the Ombudsman or that office will need additional staff to cope with the extra work. If there is an excess of capacity now, surely staff in that Ombudsman's office should have been reduced. If present capacity in an affected office of the Ombudsman does not exceed the demands being made of it now, additional staff will be needed in that office to do the bidding of the Privacy Commissioner. That being the case, why not simply attach any extra staff needed to the Commissioner's office? That surely is the sensible and straightforward thing to do.

If, as might conceivably be the case, infrequent or irregular references are anticipated and deemed justification for a part-timer to be supplied by the Ombudsman, a more sensible arrangement would involve the Commissioner's staff travelling, as required, to deal with claims. It would be cheaper; it would preserve the integrity and independence of and distance between the Ombudsman and the Privacy Commissioner. Of course, it would not avoid the likelihood of a future conflict of interest between the Privacy Commissioner and the HREOC. The more one thinks about it, the more illogical is the location of the office of the Privacy Commissioner within and subordinate to the HREOC. It could be worse, I suppose: the Privacy Commissioner could be part of the Australian Taxation Office and answerable to the Commissioner. Heaven forbid! It should not even be joked about because this Government might just do that. After all, it was the coalition that insisted on the safeguards in the principal Act as a condition of its grudging toleration of the tax file number legislation. The Government had to be dragged to the post, as it were. That is not news, of course. It is not surprising either, because this Government, in a whole host of proposals, ranging from a Bill of rights-accurately described at the time as a Bill of wrongs-to failed or abandoned referendums, has shown scant regard for the freedoms of individuals. It is little wonder that the quality of thought in amendments it now proposes to the Privacy Act 1988 is poor and inadequate.

There is great potential, and almost an inevitability, that, under the principal Act as it now stands, a conflict of interest will arise at some time in the future between the HREOC and the Privacy Commissioner. These amendments set the stage for a new conflict of interest-a conflict of interest between the Privacy Commissioner and the Ombudsman. I repeat that, if the Ombudsman has excess capacity in his officers to be able to meet these requirements, those staff should be redeployed elsewhere. If he does not, and new staff are needed, those new people should be attached to the office of the Privacy Commissioner.

If, as I have indicated, an infrequent or part time need can be established, that can be handled by the Privacy Commissioner sending his troops out into the field to the point where they have to deal with, prepare, consider, or otherwise manage a particular complaint. We need to divorce now the Privacy Commissioner from the HREOC. We also need, I suggest-and these amendments will have the opposite effect-to keep separate from the office of the Ombudsman the activities of the Privacy Commissioner. If that is all too much to ask, we should at least wait for some evidence of demand for these arrangements for the need to delegate in the absence of any information which would suggest that there is an established need.

No-one has convinced us that the Minister's second reading speech, the explanatory memoranda or, indeed, the Bill of amendment itself establishes a need to make this provision. Surely it would be better to put the Privacy Commissioner on a truly independent footing by divorcing any relationship between his office and that of the HREOC, in the first place, and by putting these amendments on the backburner, at least for the time being. There is no demonstrated need for these measures, certainly in the information that has been provided to us in the Opposition. I would very seriously suggest that the matter be allowed to lapse, as far as it offends against the principles to which I have referred in my remarks, until there is better evidence of a particular need along the lines now proposed.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is now debating amendments to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. It is an omnibus Bill covering a number of pieces of legislation under the control of the Attorney-General. Before going on to the specific provisions, I might just canvass some of the matters which have been raised in the debate by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) and the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). Firstly, this Bill's most substantive provisions relate to changes as far as the interception of telecommunications is concerned. This was the case both in creating some new offences under the Commonwealth Crimes Act concerning the manufacture, offering for sale and advertising for sale of call-switching devices and telephone interception devices and in adding the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption as one of those bodies which can have access to telephone interceptions when the need arises.

SPEECH.PARA: In doing this the Government is touching on two things. It is ensuring that telephone interceptions are used in a very limited way and that devices which can be used for this purpose are not freely available to the general public and to those who possibly have criminal intent or intent to invade privacy: so it is ensuring the rights of the individual on the one hand. But on the other hand is trying to tackle that delicate balance of extending the necessary powers to authorities and commissions charged with the responsibility of inquiring into crime in Australia.

Of course, as the honourable member for McEwen pointed out, in Queensland the Fitzgerald inquiry and now the Fitzgerald report detailed probably the most extensive system of criminal involvement and interplay with the political system certainly in this nation's history and one would imagine on an extent almost unsurpassed in the Western democracies. It certainly is frightening to think how far that corruption and malpractice could extend. That is why it is very necessary that this Parliament and the various parliaments of the Australian States have to put into place powers and responsibilities, and this seems to have an immediate effect as far as--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are turning the lights off.

—Yes. But it is very important that those powers be put into place because what we saw in Queensland was a government which simply refused to open its eyes to the existence of a problem. The most charitable interpretation which was always put on this refusal over the years by those who wished to defend the National Party in that State was that Queensland simply was immune from these sorts of things. Because Queensland was being run by good Christian gentlemen then corruption, double-dealing, prostitution, drug dealing and illicit gambling simply would not occur there.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course any suggestion of putting checks and balances into the parliamentary system such as a public accounts committee or various other mechanisms of parliamentary scrutiny was frowned upon. The idea of having pecuniary interest registers or anything of that nature was completely rejected. Any suggestions to give the police adequate powers for the actual operation of the police force were objected to not only by the police themselves-quite obviously, as events have turned out, that sort of lead was coming from the top-but also by the political system.

It is still amazing to see some members of the Opposition, such as the honourable member for Curtin, trying to defend the indefensible. There is no defence for what has happened in Queensland in a system perpetrated by the Queensland Government. That cannot be defended. Even the most cursory reading of the Fitzgerald report-and one really would have to be on another planet not to have got some sort of feeling as to what was happening in Queensland-must lead one to the conclusion that the Queensland Government presided over a systematic extension of corruption throughout that State. That simply has no parallel in any of the other Australian States. Honourable members opposite might try to throw mud and say that these things exist elsewhere. But they do not exist under a corrupt electoral system and under a parliamentary system which has been neutered. That is the peculiar and unique situation which is Queensland. By all means give credit to the current Government-the Ahern Government-for allowing the committee to proceed, but do not be fooled by it. Consider its record in terms of implementing Fitzgerald's recommendations and its very poor record of making the immediate changes suggested by Fitzgerald. Then one will come to see the reality of that Government's commitment to changing the system which led to corruption flourishing in Queensland.

The other point to which the honourable member for Curtin took particular umbrage was the idea that the Privacy Commission was going to be linked with the Office of Parliamentary Commissioner. He maintained that inevitably this would lead to conflict between the two offices. I find that to be a legitimate argument in principle but in practice clearly the Office of Ombudsman and that of the Privacy Commission have a lot in common. Both are charged with the responsibility of inquiring into the conduct of government and government departments. Certainly, given the economies the Government must impose-supported by the Opposition, one would assume; indeed, if one believed the Opposition's rhetoric they would be vastly extended by the Opposition-it is hardly consistent to say, `We think extra resources should be given to the Privacy Commission and the Commission should not be linked with the Ombudsman', and to say in the same breath, `If we ever got into government we would abolish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, anyway. We would get rid of all the safeguards and commissions which the Government has set up'. It is a slightly inconsistent argument.

I wish the honourable member for Curtin well if he is seriously arguing that the Privacy Commissioner should be given more resources and if that is going to be the policy of his party at the next election, but let us at least give it some time to see whether there are any problems with what this Bill is proposing. To me, it makes common sense that the general public should have access to the Privacy Commission. Since the Ombudsman's Office and resources are already available, to link the two, at least in the initial stages, is a very commonsense move on behalf of the Government.

The rest of the legislation is largely non-controversial. As I have mentioned, one of the more important provisions is the creation of two new offences under the Commonwealth Crimes Act regarding switching devices and telephone interception devices. Both of these devices will be prohibited, both in terms of manufacture and sale and offering for sale. That should effectively be another link in the armour of protecting individual privacy and ensuring that unlawful use of telecommunications interception is not widely experienced throughout Australia.

One point the Caucus legal and administrative committee had some difficulty with was the question of the level of imputed knowledge about these offences. I am pleased to see that it was resolved. I pay tribute in that respect to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who forcibly argued that what the Government meant by imputed knowledge should be clearly set out. That is the case with the Bill now before the House.

There have been further amendments in the telecommunications field, in particular amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act of 1979. The first allows civilian technicians to assist the Australian Federal Police in interceptions where that assistance is required, although caution must always be exercised in regard to the range of people who could have access to potentially sensitive information. It obviously makes sense that, in cases where specialised and technical assistance is required, that assistance is available to the Australian Federal Police. I do not believe the sorts of concerns that the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) outlined will arise, given both the safeguards that are built into this Bill and also the wider controls over access to information gained in interceptions.

As I also pointed out, a couple more exemptions have been added to the list where intercepted material can be given in evidence. One allows Telecom Australia to put forward evidence of an amount of a telephone bill obtained by way of technical interception. That obviously makes a bit of sense in proving how much a telephone bill is. The other one is pursuant to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act where Australia, in terms of its international relations with other countries, can allow certain evidence to be put before a magistrate in proceedings involving criminal matters in foreign countries. Again, the same sorts of controls over that are built into this legislation and the broader legislation which covers the giving of such evidence. I do not believe that should be of any great concern to the House.

A final matter which I would like to touch on is the extension of reference appeals to the Federal Court of Australia. This is a sensible extension inasmuch as it does not in any way jeopardise the position of the accused person who was found not guilty at a trial. It does allow a particular point of law to be determined. There are safeguards built in so that the identity of the individual who was acquitted shall not be disclosed through the process of this appeal. It does allow the law on a particular point to be clarified and that makes good sense.

On the whole the legislation is simply an extension of the Government's control and concern in the area of telephone intercepts and touches on other broad areas under the Attorney-General's control, none of which are particularly controversial, and as such I believe the legislation should have the support of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to support the amendment moved by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 now before the House. I hope the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) will be prepared to accept the amendment as inclusion of the phrase `classes of persons' in the Bill as it stands is far too wide and open to misinterpretation.

—Order! The honourable member for Bruce is oblivious to the fact that the amendment is not yet before the House. It will be before the Committee and it must be addressed in the Committee of the Whole.
—We will address it at that stage. As it has been foreshadowed, it is pertinent to make a comment about it at this stage.
—Of a very fleeting nature. The honourable member for Bruce may proceed.

—Other than the one amendment the Opposition will be proposing, we on this side of the House foresee no great problems with the Bill as it will further assist the efforts of various government agencies in dealing with crime, particularly organised crime, in a more expeditious manner. The one obvious criticism, of course, is that a number of the matters addressed in this Bill should have been dealt with long ago. This Bill contains numerous amendments of a policy nature and also makes minor technical amendments to legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time available to me I intend to address only what I consider to be some of the more pertinent issues. Part 3 of the Bill which deals with the amendment to the Crimes Act 1914 is certainly welcome. In essence, the clause proscribes unauthorised call-switching devices and unauthorised interception devices. As the Attorney-General mentioned in his second reading speech, call-switching devices are used to defeat attempts to trace telephone calls. It is a fact that use of unauthorised call switching devices has already been detected by people involved in the commission of betting offences.

Given that illegal bookmaking is a major problem in this country and further given that organised crime long ago realised the profits to be made in illegal bookmaking, the Government has been very slow in moving to legislate against their use. Simply speaking, when people turn their minds to it, these unauthorised call switching devices could and indeed may have much wider benefits for those involved in organised crime. The usefulness of such unauthorised devices-devices that frustrate the efforts of law enforcement agencies-is really restricted only by the imagination of the criminal involved. A sad fact, however, is that this Government has quite demonstrably been very slow to act against organised crime generally, yet there are now clear indications that organised crime is not only becoming more technologically sophisticated but also growing, despite the efforts of specialist agencies such as the National Crime Authority.

Perhaps the best example of the growth of organised crime in recent times has been the huge influx of the Chinese triads into this country. In a few short years the triads have come to dominate the heroin trade into and within Australia. Coupled with this fact has been the exploitation by the triads of the very loosely policed business migration program run by the Government's Department of Immigration, Local Government, and Ethnic Affairs. In fact, abuse of Australia's migration system as a whole is now so endemic that members not only of the Chinese triads but also of the Japanese Yakusa are able to come and go at will and unhindered.

Part 3 of the Bill also addresses a strange anomaly within the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 which prohibits the unauthorised interception of telecommunications but does not prohibit the actual devices by which unauthorised interception may be made. The amendment to the Crimes Act 1914 which this Bill will effect will henceforth make it an offence to manufacture, advertise, offer for sale, sell or possess a device by which a telecommunications interception may be effected. As the Attorney-General would be well aware, there have been numerous occasions when Telecom technicians have found unauthorised telecommunications interception devices, particularly inside the junction pillars that Telecom Australia has located on various street corners around this country.

Again, this tightening up of existing legislation could perhaps have been done at a much earlier stage. I am given to understand that such devices are still available at many electronics shops and I would hope that all such retail outlets still selling these items will be notified, if they have not been already, of these changes to the law. Additionally, I would hope that the Government will take into account the possibility that many of the thousands of electronics buffs around Australia may have some of these devices tucked away in their workshops, not because they harbour a desire to intercept someone's telephone calls but simply because, like all buffs of a particular subject matter, they squirrel away anything that has a bearing on their subject of interest. It would be a travesty if one or more of these enthusiasts were to end up facing criminal proceedings because they were not aware that the law had been changed and that possession of such a device had-once this Bill is passed-become an offence.

I turn now to part 8 of the Bill-the amendment of the Customs Act 1901. This amendment obviously reflects some concern that a possible interpretation by the courts of `premises' may be challenged in relation to the situation of listening devices if it has not already been. Certainly as far as interpretation of the law is concerned, this amendment, in that it more clearly defines what a premise is as regards the law, will tighten up any loophole that may provide a legal avenue of escape for an alleged offender.

I turn now to Part 11 of the Bill, the amendments of the Privacy Act 1988. Whilst I applaud the apparent cost-effectiveness of the amendments and the more convenient access they will provide to individuals wishing to approach the Privacy Commissioner, I ask the Attorney-General whether he can tell the House what effect this will have on the workload of the various Ombudsman's offices around Australia. If the impact will be sufficient to detract from the Ombudsman's own existing workload, this will weaken the Ombudsman's effectiveness, which will in turn be detrimental to the overall public interest. In that particular respect I share the concerns already expressed in this debate by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). Notwithstanding the particular reservations about this legislation which I have addressed and, of course, foreshadowing support for the amendment which will be moved ultimately by our own shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies, the Opposition on balance supports the Bill the Government has brought before the House today. In my view there has been unwarranted procrastination in dealing with a variety of matters covered by the Government's legislation, but it is overall a responsible Bill.

It does not have offices in South Australia, Western Australia, Victoria, et cetera. So it has to rely, as it often does, on the State administrations to come into arrangements to investigate matters relating to the rights of people. It has never created any problem, nor will this create any problem. The reason for this is to give the people a chance to have matters, as it says, `prepared'. Honourable members will notice that the proposal is that they would get assistance in the preparation of their complaints and in the investigation of their complaints, but the determination would be made by the Privacy Commissioner. That has to be understood, and the honourable member for Menzies did understand it; that is why he did not raise it. That is the issue that has to be made clear.

The honourable member for Menzies did raise a point that has got what one would call some kick in the case. He said, `What is the idea of bringing in here an amendment on telephone interception which would allow the police to be assisted by classes of persons?'. That is a reasonable question to ask, but then he proposed an amendment which I cannot accept, because he proposes to omit `classes of persons'. That definition is worrying him. It is important that, when we are dealing with interception, we have people who might have different skills. These people would be members of the Australian Federal Police, but they would not be police as such. They would have the technical capacity to assist in interception but they would be under the obligations and all the normal requirements of members of the Australian Federal Police. There is a reference in the Bill to section 16 of the Australian Federal Police Act. This is not a new matter. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 contains the following amendment which was introduced in 1987:

The Commissioner of Police, or a member of the Australian Federal Police in relation to whom an appointment . . . is in force, may approve in writing members of the Australian Federal Police, or classes of members of the Australian Federal Police, to exercise the authority conferred by warrants or classes of warrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they're police officers, aren't they?

—No, they are not necessarily police officers. They are classes. The other people-about whom the honourable member makes the point-are also members of the Australian Federal Police. I cannot accept the amendment because they would be within the control of the Australian Federal Police; they would not be outside it. They would not be police as such. They would be technical officers, but employed by the police and they would be referred to as being in that class.

SPEECH.PARA: I think honourable members generally welcome the amendments. There has been some criticism on matters of delay and things of that nature. I do not know that those criticisms are valid, but I am not going to argue against them. The issue of resources has again been raised in the privacy area. The Privacy Commissioner would make additional resources available to the Ombudsman if there were concern about that. The amendment that I wish to move later, and which I will address then, relates to the fact that clause 31 of the Bill proposes that the issue of giving assistance in terms of preparation and investigation of privacy complaints could be carried out by members of the staff of the Ombudsman. The Ombudsman himself said that that is a little bit too wide. My amendment proposes that this will apply only where there is a delegation by the Privacy Commissioner. This would confine such an activity and I think the amendment would make the Bill more effective.

I wish to refer to a couple of other minor matters. When reading my second reading speech back in May, I foreshadowed that there may have been a request from the Norfolk Island authorities who were concerned that section 11 of the State and Territorial Laws and Records Recognition Act would override a particular provision of the Legislative Assembly's Privileges Act of 1967. We have been subsequently advised by the administration of the Northern Territory that there would be no inconsistency between the two provisions and, accordingly, the Norfolk Island authorities have withdrawn their request. I am just advising the House of that.

There was an error in the second reading speech in respect of clause 25 which I am told related to a matter that the honourable member for Menzies properly raised. The second reading speech referred to the ability `to prohibit evidence being given in Australia for use in civil or criminal proceedings'. The reference to `civil or criminal proceedings' was in error and should have been to civil and commercial proceedings. I express my apologies to the House and I thank the honourable member of Menzies for bringing it to our attention. For the record, I should refer to one other matter. A correction in the explanatory memorandum, which has been tabled, relates to the various clauses that needed some technical amendment. The correction has been circulated.

This omnibus Bill produces some effective law reform. The honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) is worried about criminal penetration, as the whole world is. I would not want it to go unnoticed that we spend a lot of time and a lot of resources and, in fact, introduce a lot of new law in order to do something about combating criminal activity. I do not know that we are failing; I would not accept that. Nevertheless, it is acknowledged that we need to be ever vigilant. We do require good law enforcement officers and we do require good intelligence. I think we have a lot of mechanisms in place that relate to that. We have the National Crime Authority, we have mutual assistance treaties which did not exist before, and we have extradition treaties which did not exist before. They now number 40. In fact, one of the busiest aspects of my Department at present is that dealing with extradition.

As regards at the international conventions on narcotics control, there is understanding that there has to be a lot of coordination between countries. Criminals travel fast and their money travels even faster. We have already got the confiscation of assets in and we are getting results because of that. Nevertheless, the issue will always require a continual effort, and I do not think we are going to be behind anybody else in this regard.

The legislation we have in place is very effective indeed. But we do need the personnel to run those pieces of legislation. That relates to the National Crime Authority, it relates to all police forces and, without getting back into Queensland-which I think is not really the issue in front of us-the question is how to attract people to law enforcement agencies, and do they have other skills. At the present time I am encouraging the Australian Federal Police, through my colleague Senator Tate, to recruit on a contract basis people who have other skills and are able to look at the balance sheets and talk about where money moves.

We have the Crown's cash transaction position in place, and we are now getting good cooperation from the banks in the giving of information, though this matter is the subject of some minor amendments I have to introduce soon. This relates certainly to tax evasion but it is also very beneficial because it is clear that the sorts of people that the honourable member refers to deal basically in very substantial amounts of cash. I do not think the legislation is defective at all. The new head of the National Crime Authority is very talented and is very interested in the pursuit of criminal behaviour.

Let me pay a tribute to members of my own profession who give up their careers at the Bar to take on these positions for two or three years and then have to go back to the Bar, having lost most of their practice in the meantime. They suffer a pecuniary penalty by so doing. The honourable member for Menzies would know something of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as much as you did.

—No, but I thought you might come in on another point. We always have to make a sacrifice, as he knows. But the point that I am making is that a lot of effort is being made and we do need more cooperation. I thank honourable members for their contribution.
—Does the Minister have in mind tabling the corrections to the explanatory memorandum?
—I formally table them.
