TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 31, page 12, lines 6 to 8, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Complaints
``31. Section 36 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (4) and substituting the following subsection:
`(4) It is the duty of:
(a) members of the staff of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission; and
(b) members of the staff of the Ombudsman who have had powers of the Commissioner delegated to them under section 99;
to provide appropriate assistance to a person who wishes to make a complaint and requires assistance to formulate the complaint.'.''.

Clause 31 of the Bill is omitted and a revised clause 31 substituted, which will insert an amended subsection 36 (4) into the Privacy Act. The amendment is to meet the concern expressed by the Ombudsman himself that the duty to assist individuals in preparing and investigating privacy complaints falls only on those of his staff who have a delegation from the Privacy Commissioner under section 99 of the Privacy Act. I think that is adequate and I say no more.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 32 to 43-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 44 (Who may exercise authority conferred by warrant).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 44, page 15, lines 14 and 15, omit ``, or classes of persons,''.

The substance of this amendment, as I have already explained, is to omit the words `or classes of persons' from the description of those designated technical officers who are going to assist members of the Australian Federal Police to carry out telephone interceptions. As I said in the second reading debate when I foreshadowed this amendment, the concern is that quite extensive powers are being given to the people who will assist the officers of the Australian Federal Police in carrying out this very significant activity, namely, telephone interceptions. As I have said, the people who will be giving the assistance are not just carrying the lunch box, they are in fact installing the equipment. They are undertaking a very significant task. Not only are they installing the equipment; they are maintaining it, testing it and using it. Presumably, that means they are listening in. They are also responsible for the removal of the equipment.

The intention is that the Commissioner of Police declare people who are to be designated technical officers for the purpose of carrying out this function. It should be noted-this takes it one step further-that it is not just a case of the Commissioner of Police knowing the classes of persons who are going to be designated to carry out this function; it is the Commissioner of Police, or someone who has already been given approval to carry out that function of the Commissioner of Police. Therefore, it is already one step removed. As I said, the Commissioner of Police or a person who is an approving officer will have the power to declare these persons to be designated technical officers. We should be cautious when we get to that stage, and we should be doubly cautious, I believe, when it is not merely persons-that is, named and individual persons-who are going to be given this considerable power, but classes of persons. Presumably, there will not be hundreds or dozens of them. I imagine that comparatively few persons, albeit hard working, will be involved. If that is the case, can they not be identified by name?

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot.

—Well, change the authority. It is not the end of the world: change the designation. Presumably they will change. But if one declares a class, people will wander into and out of this function like a nomadic tribe because they will be part of a declared class. Correct me if I am wrong, but the class that will be designated will be a class such as all persons of a particular grading, or all persons of a particular rank, classification or technical grouping. It will involve all persons employed who come within that description. Their names will not be designated. That really seems to us to be too broad. Even if only for an excess of caution, it would seem appropriate to take out the words `or classes of persons'. It will not do any harm. It will not cause a heavy burden of additional work, because there must surely be comparatively few of these people who will be carrying out this function.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to help my opponent the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), but I am advised that his amendment really does not help us. The expression `classes of persons' certainly creates an issue as to whether there will be an unknown number. They certainly will not be named, but they will not be unknown. The clause states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner of Police or a person who is an approving officer under subsection (3), may, in writing, declare persons, or classes of persons, to be designated technical officers . . .
They are very small in number, I understand. Proposed new subsection (5) states:
A reference in subsection (4) to the provision of technical assistance-
the emphasis is on the words `technical assistance'-
includes a reference to the doing of any act in connection with . . .

It then refers to installation, maintenance and removal. I understand that these officers will not do the actual installation, maintenance or removal but will be giving the police advice as to what to do in this technical capacity because the police would not have the technical capacity. In other words, they would be supervising. That is why I am saying that these people are public servants-I had better get that bit right-in the police force, not actual police officers. I correct what I said earlier. The definition is compatible with the earlier definition in the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act-which has already been approved by the Parliament-where we see again that:

The Commissioner of Police, or a member of the Australian Federal Police in relation to whom an appointment under subsection (3) is in force, may approve in writing members of the Australian Federal police, or classes of members of the Australian Federal Police . . .

The honourable gentleman feels that there is some unknown group out there that nobody has any control over. I do not see any problem. They are a group designated by the Commissioner of Police. Bear in mind that the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act states that the Commissioner of Police-not only the Commissioner himself-may appoint in writing a member of the Australian Federal Police to be an approving officer for the purpose of doing something in respect of authority under a warrant. This applies not only to the Commissioner but to a person under him. We have that chain of command. The Commissioner or somebody approved by him will authorise this group. They will certainly be technical officers, but the police themselves will be doing the actual installation. Whilst I can understand the honourable gentleman's view, I think there is an adequate safeguard there, rather than going to the point of our having to name these people, who will change from time to time in the normal course of employment. I do not think it creates any weakness in the adequate protection of the rights of individuals who feel that their particular privacy or other matters may be interfered with.

Let me say to the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) as an old Postmaster-General-not Attorney-General-that the situation is very clear when one has technical complaints about one's phone. Technical officers put intercepts in to see how it works. They do it all the time through the exchange-not that I would want to make a long speech about it here. But there has always been a capacity, in a technical sense, to work out how a person's line may be malfunctioning. Basically it is that same skill that is going to be used to guarantee that the particular equipment that might be used in this situation functions properly. It is not a new matter from the point of view of technical assistance.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-read a third time.

Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Madam Speaker, in presenting last year's Budget I said that Australia was on the way to a systematic restructuring of its economy, making it more dynamic and more able to compete in the world.
Tonight, I can report that we are further down the road of that fundamental restructuring than we were a year ago.
That is because the past year has seen the consolidation of the most significant investment phase since Federation.
And it is investment which is the key to a successful fight back on the trade front.
But we have had our set-backs and still have a long way to go-a generation of neglect cannot quickly be put right.
We are under no illusion that there have been disappointments.
Last year inflation was too high.
And the balance of payments did not fall as we expected, leading to higher interest rates.
This has been the price we paid for the massive modernisation of Australian industry.
The challenge before us now is to get the best from this stronger economic structure.
To turn it against our trade and inflation problems-the only way we can secure sustainably lower interest rates.
Madam Speaker, tonight's Budget takes up this challenge.
It declares a record surplus-the third Budget surplus in a row.
Real Government spending is cut for the fourth year in succession, to its lowest share in 16 years.

It tackles Australia's savings problem-the proper way, with a far-sighted restructuring of retirement incomes policy to encourage today's working Australians to save for their retirement through superannuation.
And as we promised in April, the Budget fully funds the largest tax cut and family package in our history.
Madam Speaker, it is a Budget without gimmicks-without resort to quick fixes.
It is a Budget which puts the nation's interests first.
THE BUDGET OUTCOME
Madam Speaker, a year ago I forecast a Budget surplus of $5 1/2 billion.
The result was even better, close to $6 billion.
The Budget I bring down tonight will deliver a surplus of $9.1 billion.
A massive deposit in the savings account of the nation.
What a contrast with the situation left to us by the Liberals in 1983!
Then Australia's Budget was in the red by a record $9 billion.
Today, it is in the black by $9 billion.
That is prudent Government the Labor way.
In six years we conquered the largest and most profligate fiscal deficit in the nation's history, reducing it to zero-we have now produced a surplus of the same enormous dimension.
And the Government has refunded more in tax cuts than if we had fully indexed the tax scales for inflation since 1983.
Of special importance, this year's Commonwealth surplus will more than offset the borrowing by all state and local Governments in Australia.
This year the Public Sector Borrowing Requirement is forecast to be in surplus by 1.2 per cent of GDP.
Every cent of the Commonwealth's $9 billion surplus will be used to pay back debt.
This will mean that over a four-year span total Commonwealth debt to GDP will have been reduced by half.
SAVINGS AND RETIREMENT INCOMES POLICY
Madam Speaker, in recent times there has been a lot of talk about measures to boost domestic savings.
Higher national savings are undoubtedly part and parcel of overcoming our balance of payments problems.
That is one basic reason why we have moved the Budget so heavily into surplus, to increase public savings and to pay off debt.
But there is a distinction to be made between good and bad schemes intended to stimulate private savings.
The Government is not about to grasp half-baked ideas on savings simply to satisfy some passing fashion.
Rather, our approach over six years has been to plan and pursue a structured and certain path, cutting tax rates and extending the benefit of superannuation savings to the whole workforce.
The task before us now is to plan for early next century when the large post-war ``baby boom'' generation will be reaching retirement age.
This year about 13 per cent of the population is of pensionable age-that will rise to around 25 per cent by the year 2030.
Consequently, tonight I am announcing a comprehensive reform of the retirement income policies of this country.
A detailed statement is being simultaneously released by my colleague, the Minister for Social Security.
Our goal is to encourage those now in the prime of their working lives to provide a higher standard of living for themselves in retirement.

We will do that by maintaining and improving the age pension and by providing better opportunities and incentives to save for retirement through superannuation-to supplement rather than to diminish the pension.
A key feature of this package is a far-reaching plan to integrate the taxation and social security income testing systems.
It builds on the April Statement change which exempted the pension income test free area entirely from tax.
That change alone ensures that 80 per cent of all age pensioners will be totally excluded from any requirement to pay tax.
Tonight I announce that the tax-free income area for pensioners will in future be indexed to keep pace with the cost of living.
Beyond that, the Government tonight commits itself to an even more far-reaching reform.
From 1995 all age and service pensioners-that is both full rate and part rate pensioners-will be totally removed from the tax system.
In other words, all age and service pensioners will be subject only to the social security income test-they will not have to pay tax.
This will make it much more rewarding for retirees to have an additional source of income to the pension.
The message to today's working Australians is that saving for your retirement will be rewarded, not penalised.
A whole range of complementary changes will be implemented to make superannuation more worthwhile.
Chief among these are effective rules to ensure that superannuation paid on behalf of employees is not lost to them when they change jobs.
At the same time the requirements to preserve these superannuation payments until people actually retire will be enhanced.

The limit on tax deductions self-employed people can claim for putting aside superannuation will be increased, and in future, other workers on low or modest incomes with relatively small employer-funded superannuation will be able to top-up those funds and claim tax deductions.
Furthermore, the maximum permissible superannuation benefit available to low and middle-income workers is to be dramatically increased.

But to add further momentum to private provision in retirement and provide an extra boost to national savings, the Government will consider as part of the wage system for next financial year the gradual introduction of a further 3 per cent award for occupational superannuation.
Madam Speaker, these historic reforms confirm superannuation as the Government's preferred savings vehicle.
Over time this policy will be central to the national imperative to lift savings.
Already the shift in superannuation savings since 1983 has been remarkable, especially since superannuation was made available to the entire workforce.
Last year superannuation assets grew by $15 billion.
That increase in a single year was about the same size as the total assets of superannuation funds when this Government came to office in 1983.
Today total assets stand at $105 billion-larger than Australia's net overseas debt.
Our reforms will build dramatically on that base.
On the basis of present trends, by the turn of the century more than $60 billion a year will be flowing into superannuation funds-a massive injection to the nation's savings pool.
A savings program which will really enhance national savings and not a gimmick which would grotesquely distort the economy.
In this way the retirement incomes policy is a strategy for coming decades, not just coming years.
But, Madam Speaker, I stress that the maintenance of an adequate age pension system will remain the essential element underpinning our retirement incomes policy.
The Labor Party's long-standing commitment to an age pension of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings will be put beyond any shadow of a doubt in this Budget.
Next April the normal indexation increase will lift the single rate pension by about $9 a fortnight.
Tonight I am announcing that over and above that rise, the pension will be increased by $4 a fortnight, a total rise of $13.
From April 1990, the return of the after-tax purchase price of annuities will be freed from the social security income test.
In addition, from November this year age pensioners will be able to borrow up to $40,000 against the value of their home without having this extra money counted in the social security income test.
Pensioners who do not own their own homes are also to be further assisted.
From this December basic rental assistance will be increased from $15 to $20 per week, with two further $5 rises to follow next year.
That will mean that from September 1990 rent assistance of up to $30 a week will be provided for pensioners without children, rising to $40 per week for families with three or more children.
For aged pensioners the measures announced during this year will cost over $700 million, while the full-year cost of all social security measures will be $1.7 billion.
OUTLAYS
Madam Speaker, I now turn to the outlays side of the Budget.
In 1989-90, outlays or Commonwealth spending will represent 23.7 per cent of the economy, the lowest level since 1973-74.
A fall of 6 percentage points of GDP in six years.
The forward estimates, now published in the Budget documents, point to further decline.
That is, three years from now Labor will have succeeded in reducing Commonwealth Government spending to the levels of the 1950s.
This restraint enables us to be responsive to changing circumstances and to improve the effectiveness and fairness of government spending.
We have made a smaller public sector a better public sector.
Better targeting those in need and being more generous to those who are most deserving.
Need I say, Madam Speaker, we reject completely the notion that Australia will somehow be a better place by walking away from the community's collective responsibility to assist the least well off.
It is because of this better management of public finances that we have also been able to address other high priority areas in this Budget.
These have included the Prime Minister's environment statement, his re-commitment to a multi-cultural Australia and the initiatives outlined to enhance our scientific effort.
Tonight, Madam Speaker, in a further re-evaluation of priorities the Government is announcing a number of new initiatives to advance its social justice objectives.
The first is to assist the most needy experiencing difficulties with rent and mortgage repayments.
The Government will provide an extra $15 million to be distributed under the existing Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme administered by State Housing Authorities on behalf of the Commonwealth.

A National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy is to be established, drawing together a number of hitherto separate programs, to tackle the severe educational disadvantage of this group.
Expenditure is estimated at $89 million in 1990-an increase of $34 million on 1989.
The Commonwealth Employment Service will be revamped to provide even more help for those having difficulties in the labour market, including the older unemployed.
Payments to the single unemployed aged between 60 and 64 and out of work for six months or more will be aligned with the single age pension rate and increased by $17 per fortnight.
Another initiative deals with one of our most disturbing social issues-that of homeless youth.
We have developed a comprehensive strategy to address their needs at a cost of $24 million in both this year and next: further details are outlined in the Budget Papers.
In the health and community services area the Government has also committed additional funds to high priority areas.
The comprehensive AIDS strategy, designed to limit the advance of the disease will receive an additional $7 million this year, rising to $14 million in 1990-91.

Over the next two years the Government will be providing an additional $44 million to encourage participation and excellence in sport which plays such a vital role in the collective life of this nation.
REVENUE
I now turn to the revenue side of the Budget.
This year revenue as a share of the economy is estimated at 26.2 per cent, the same level as last year and 1.5 percentage points lower than in 1986-87.
It is also the same level that obtained under the last two Liberal Budgets before this Government came to office.
Just as importantly, Madam Speaker, the Government has reformed the Australian taxation system, making it both fairer and more efficient.
Tonight I announce further changes.
First to the company tax system.
Under current arrangements company tax is collected with much greater lags than taxes paid by individuals.
Because of these delays companies enjoy an interest free loan from the Government for up to two years.
We have decided to narrow this concessional arrangement.
This will bring forward $885 million in revenue this year but, more significantly, will generate an ongoing saving in public debt interest of about $330 million per year.
Deferral of tax payments also arises with monthly remittances of PAYE tax withheld by employers.
The Government has decided that, from 1 December 1989, the 800 or so largest employers, with annual remittances exceeding $5 million, will be required to make payments twice a month rather than once.
This will bring forward $550 million of revenue and will further reduce public debt interest by $70 million in a full year.
To assist long-term business planning, the seven-year carry forward of losses is to be removed, allowing unlimited carry forward of losses incurred in 1989-90 and beyond.
Sales tax on small business will be reduced by substantially increasing the manufacturers' exemption from $12,000 to $50,000; aids to manufacture provisions are also being extended.
The Government has also undertaken a major review of the taxation treatment of Life Offices.
From 1 January 1990, expenses incurred by life insurance companies in gaining the investment component of premium income will be tax deductible.
The Government has also decided to exempt from tax non-profit sports and games clubs, such as pony and fishing clubs.
As well, community service organisations such as Lions and Rotary clubs will be exempted from tax.
The Government will also relieve some 130,000 taxpayers from paying quarterly provisional tax by raising the threshold to $8,000.
Madam Speaker, the Government's relentless war on tax avoidance will continue.
I am announcing tonight further anti-avoidance measures in the areas of capital gains tax, dividend selection schemes and share-based financing arrangements.
The Government is proud of its tax reforms and will continue to pursue the objective of a fair and reasonable taxation system.
ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND POLICY
I return now to economic conditions and policy.
At the outset I referred to the surge of business investment which last year grew by a massive 15 per cent in real terms.
But at the same time as companies were spending heavily on investment goods, private spending elsewhere in the economy was also rising strongly.
The overall effect was that domestic demand in Australia grew too fast, spilling over into imports, diverting export goods to the local market, and rekindling inflationary pressures.
Let me underline that point.
Last financial year national spending increased by nearly 8 per cent in real terms.
Yet gross domestic product-the measure of everything we produce in Australia-grew by under 4 per cent.
That big gap-spending at 8 per cent and production at 4 per cent-sums up our trade problem.
It is a gap which must be closed.
In the short term that can only be done by bringing that high demand down to a more realistic level.
This is where interest rates have played an appropriate role.
It is also why the Government has continued with tight budgetary and wages policies.
But moderating demand is only half the story.
The other half is lifting our local supply of goods and services-our production.
This involves more investment but spread more evenly over time.
It involves more entrepreneurial management.
It involves better work practices and greater skills in the workforce.
And it involves more efficiency in our economic structure-being even smarter in the way we get things done.
These are reasons why the Government welcomes the recent Industrial Relations Commission decision, completing the framework for the most far-reaching overhaul of industrial awards since Federation.
Madam Speaker, wages policy has also been fundamental to our economic success.
Throughout the past six years the Government's unique Accord with the Australian workforce has delivered unprecedented wage restraint.
There are now 1.5 million more Australians in jobs than there were six years ago-a phenomenal figure and one of this Labor Government's proudest achievements.
The unemployment rate has fallen from 11 per cent to 6 per cent, its lowest level for 8 years.
At this very moment the Accord is protecting the employment gains of the past six years from the ravages of a wage explosion.
It has enabled the Government to negotiate a wage/tax trade off to protect investment and to fend off recession.
In the period immediately ahead the award restructuring process will bring about a much more adaptable and flexible labour market.
Those historic changes build upon the other economic reforms that this Government has aggressively pursued.
A modern financial system, a fairer tax system, reduced trade barriers and better education and training systems.
More recently these far-reaching reforms have extended to the waterfront and the communications industry.
Madam Speaker, as the only Government in Australia's post-war history that has attempted such structural changes to the economy, we are well aware of the need to press on with reform.
To this end we have decided to restructure the existing Industries Assistance Commission, greatly broadening its charter to act as a catalyst for dynamic change in industry.
Reflecting these changes, the expanded body will be renamed the Industry Commission.
I am announcing details of these changes, together with a major two-year work program for the Commission, in a separate statement.
ECONOMIC PROSPECTS
Madam Speaker, I now turn to Australia's economic prospects.
From what I have said before it is clear that in the past year the major preoccupation of policy was with an economy which was too buoyant.
The fallout from that was higher than expected prices and greater than forecast imports.
But during the course of the current year we expect this momentum to moderate in response to past tightening of policies.
So in the period ahead we plan for a necessary slowdown in spending.
However, I stress this does not mean a recessed economy.
It is production, not spending, that generates jobs and spending has a long way to fall before it reaches our production otential.
Vital business investment will still stay strong with growth in the plant and equipment component expected to remain robust.
This will ensure the economy maintains sufficient momentum for growth in gross domestic product of 2 3/4 per cent and employment growth of the same magnitude.
We are confident of achieving the transition to a more sustainable growth path without destroying activity.
Madam Speaker, the pattern of moderating demand will mean that many key aggregates will be lower in the second half of the financial year than in the first.
This is the case with inflation and the balance of payments, where recent momentum will carry on for a time.
Thus, while the increase in the CPI is expected to be little changed at around 7 1/2 per cent for the year as a whole, it will be running noticeably below that in 1990.
The Government is determined to secure that lower inflation trend.
As a community we must reduce inflation.
With demand slowing, the growth of imports will also slow, and quite sharply as the year progresses.
Even so, for the full year the current account deficit is forecast to be equivalent to about 5 per cent of GDP, only a slight improvement on last year.
Again, however, by the second half of the year the deficit will be running a good deal below that, as the much weaker trend in imports and the pickup in exports emerge.
But to stabilise our international debt the current account deficit will have to continue to be reduced.
The full force of this Government's resolve will be directed to this end.
All in all, the substantial Budget surplus, the forecast slowing in demand and the expected improvement in the balance of payments, establish a framework for lower interest rates.
However, I stress that rates cannot and should not fall until it is economically responsible.
This Government is not prepared to countenance a premature fall in interest rates.
When the time is right, we are confident that the economic fundamentals will produce a sustainable fall.
CONCLUSION
Madam Speaker, as a result of the Government's economic policies Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving.
This will occur because the Government has kept sight on its objectives and not been diverted by superficial solutions to fundamental problems.
It has never sought to minimise its responsibilities or shy away from the issues of substance.
The Australian people have responded to these realities by adopting a highly responsible attitude.
They have quite sensibly rejected sham solutions to the country's difficulties.
They are looking for value and consistency.
In short, Madam Speaker, they are looking for the meat rather than the feathers.
This Budget will fulfill that national purpose.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Social Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the information of honourable members I present a paper entitled Better Incomes: Retirement Income Policy into the Next Century.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement is the most comprehensive policy on retirement income in Australia's history. It has been developed through wide and extensive consultation with all interested groups. The issues are well known and the solutions are generally agreed, even though there may be some differences about details. In this statement we step beyond the short term to a policy about the long term future of Australia and our retired people. This Government's retirement incomes policy is built on the firm foundation of social security, taxation and wages policy over the last six years. Without the reconstruction of the social security and taxation systems of the last six years it would not have been possible to develop or adopt a policy that is fair, adequate, secure and sustainable.

In tandem with the Government's economic strategy, this policy addresses, in a fundamental way, the level of national savings. Savings for retirement is long term and not directed to short-term consumption. It helps ensure sustained economic growth and reduces our dependence on overseas borrowing. This retirement income policy is a policy to deliver better incomes for those retired now and those who will retire in the future. It is a fair, adequate, secure and sustainable policy. It is a policy about better incomes now and into the next century.

Retirement issues affect everyone, one way or another, throughout their lives. The policy is fair to everyone. It is fair to people currently retired. For people dependent on the age pension it provides a real sustainable increase in incomes. The Government is committed to the age pension system. For the first time it will be integrated with private retirement savings. The interaction of private savings particularly through superannuation, pensions and tax will be reformed in three steps. Firstly, by 1990 the pension income test free area will be 100 per cent tax free. Secondly, from 1991 the social security-and tax-income free areas will be indexed. Thirdly, from 1995 the tax and social security systems will be better integrated, so that no age or service pensioner, full rate or part rate, will pay income tax. At that time the present withdrawal rates will be substantially reduced to 50 per cent.

This policy statement also marks an historic new fair deal for women in retirement income. Changes in the superannuation system will mean that, for the first time ever, women who have time out of the work force or who work part time will have access to superannuation. Wages policy and superannuation policy will mean that the number of women covered by superannuation will rapidly increase. This Government established award based superannuation as part of wages policy. Award based superannuation is the best and fairest means of providing superannuation to the majority of the work force. The Government supports the principle of the extension of award based superannuation. It is through award based superannuation that most women will get the opportunity to benefit from superannuation.

Superannuation changes will mean that in the future widows will be entitled to far better reversionary benefits on the death of their husbands. Over time, retiring couples are far more likely to take an annuity with the security of an adequate reversionary benefit for the widow when her husband dies.

Couples will have the opportunity to make sure that women are not left widowed without adequate income. The policy is also fair to the many thousands of women widowed before they could benefit from these changes. It enables these women to use the equity in their homes to supplement their income without affecting their pension-and provides substantial increases for those who do not own their home but pay private rent. The Government rejects the argument that fairness requires a decision to lift the age pension age for women. We will monitor the progress of women's access to superannuation and the labour market before consideration of any change to the age pension age for women.

Our retirement income policy is all about better incomes-better incomes for all in retirement. This policy statement reaffirms our firm commitment to the age pension system and to tax assisted superannuation. In April 1990 we will not only meet, but exceed Labor's longstanding commitment to an age pension of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We will maintain the value of the pension through indexation in line with the consumer price index-at the earliest possible date after publication of CPI figures-and we commit ourselves to further increases in the age pension, over time.

Income needs of people who have not had the opportunity to save during their working lives will be met under this policy. Adequate retirement income is much broader than an adequate pension. On top of the age pension, rent assistance reforms mean that in over just 10 months-from December 1989 to September 1990-we will double rent assistance for age and service pensioners, from $15 to $30 per week. For the first time ever rent assistance will be indexed.

This policy also contains a package of measures that will make annuities a far more attractive option for people as they retire. The package includes changes in the superannuation system to reasonable benefit rules, lifting the maximum level of reversionary benefits for widows and freeing up arrangements for smaller funds to provide annuities. In the social security system the bias against annuities in the income test will be removed. This policy means that superannuation and other savings can now be used effectively as a source of retirement income-lifting the levels of retirement income.

Mr Deputy Speaker, retirement income is not a short term matter. Young people starting off on 40 years of a working life need to be able to save for their retirement with security. This statement includes a program for changes well into the next century. For the first time ever Australia's workers can plan for retirement on a secure footing. That secure footing includes the guarantee of indexation of every component of the age pension system. The basic pension is indexed. Assets test limits are indexed. After the substantial increases in rates, rent assistance will be indexed from March 1991. From 1991 the tax free income test free area will be indexed.

All child payments are automatically adjusted for inflation. People who have retired and those who will retire in the future now have the security of knowing that inflation will not erode the adequacy of any part of the age pension system. Retired people also need access to reliable information about social security and tax rules. This policy includes provision for advisory and information services so that retired people can have the security of access to reliable information about how best to manage their retirement income.

Most importantly this policy is sustainable. Like every element of the Government's social policies, the retirement income changes in this statement will be fully funded on introduction. The changes mean that as time goes by more and more people will retire with better access to superannuation and other private income. Because we have reconstructed the social security system over the last six years and because we have built a fair superannuation system we can now integrate private retirement savings, the public pension and the tax system. Through these steps as a community we will be able to make the change to provide better incomes in retirement into the next century not simply for those Australians for the next decade or so but for all Australians into the future. We can have for the first time in this country's history a balanced retirement income system operating on the twin pillars of our age pension system effectively linked and integrated with annuities and superannuation-a genuine and sustainable retirement income system. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the statement to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement just made by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is significant in a number of respects. Firstly, it does contain some worthwhile changes to the system, and I give him full compliment for that. However, it is interesting to note that in the very first sentence of his statement he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first comprehensive policy on retirement income in Australian history.

I think I should put on the record that in fact the first comprehensive policy on retirement income in Australia's history was announced by the coalition parties in November 1988. I should also put on record that many of the benefits, many of the worthwhile elements of this package, were in fact contained in that document. I am pleased, and the Opposition is delighted, that in the interests of the welfare of the Australian people the Government has seen fit to absorb our proposals in its Budget arrangements tonight. It is a good thing for Australians, especially in areas such as retirement income, that it is possible for both sides of the House to agree on the long-term objectives of such a policy. As the Minister quite rightly points out, it has to be a policy for the long term. But it would have been nice, I think, and appropriate for a man who claims to have some statesmanlike qualities on occasions, for him to have perhaps given some credit to the work of the Opposition in this particular role.

Our policy predated the Cass Social Security Review report; it predated the reports put out by the Life Insurance Federation of Australia and various organisations in the life insurance and superannuation industry. We believed then, and we believe now, that with an ageing population there are few, if any, more significant issues on the public agenda of this nation than the protection of our aged, both now and in the future. It has been a matter of great regret to us that over the last seven years and seven Budgets of the Hawke Labor Government and Keating as Treasurer we have seen time after time changes being introduced which were at best ad hoc and which at worst introduced into the retirement income formula the most dangerous word of all-and that was doubt: doubt on the stability of policy; doubt on people's capacity to plan and save over 30 or 40 years of their lives; and doubt as to what in fact the end benefits would be.

Why was there that doubt? It was simply because, within six months of this Government being elected to power, it made some fundamental changes in the tax mix of superannuation. It said then that that would be the beginning and the end of the exercise. In April of last year we saw another set of fundamental changes which in fact negatived all those that had been introduced a few years before. Again we were told by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on that occasion-and I can paraphrase his words because they are indelibly branded on my mind-that the people of Australia could plan with confidence in their future because now the ball was in the right park and there would be no further change.

Here we see again, in the next Budget, a further set of changes. While, as I have said, there has been some step forward-and I would be the last person to deny that fact-it is a very sad day for Australia when the pensioners of this country, the retirees, and those who are nearing retirement are once again faced with a whole set of changes. And they wonder when the next set will be. In the highly unlikely event that this Government is returned, I presume we will see yet another few then.

The Minister also made the observation that, in tandem with the Government's economic strategy, this policy addresses in a fundamental way the level of national savings. I wonder how many people will see that statement in the context of some 18 per cent interest rate on housing and 7 per cent inflation, which, as the Government has acknowledged in the Budget introduced in this House tonight, it is not its objective to reduce. Effectively, the Government has said it cannot help the problem. What has now been done-rightly in the short term; I emphasise that short term-is that the Government has said to the pensioners of Australia and to those on low incomes who are dependent on the welfare system, `We are going to index everything'. For all intents and purposes, that is what it has done.

If one reads carefully the 1989-90 Budget information document put out by the Minister for Social Security, one finds the most interesting thing-that most of the changes he is introducing will not affect the next financial year and some will not affect the financial year after that. Goodness gracious me, we find that in fact the changes go right through to 1995 when, we are told, in those grandiose tones used by both the Treasurer and now the Minister for Social Security, all pensioners, whether full pensioners or part pensioners, will be fully integrated into the tax system, which is something I happen to support. But he goes on to say that they will not have to pay any tax.

The trouble is this: there will be an awful lot of pensioners out there tonight who will say, `Goodness gracious me, am I going to live that long?'. Why is it, if these policy objectives are so wonderful, that it will take six years before they are introduced? I asked some of my colleagues who have great knowledge in such matters whether they recalled any government ever in Australia's history having the effrontery to come into this House in the context of a Budget and say, `We are making commitments six years down the track'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do it all the time.

—The Minister for Defence says, `Yes, we do it all the time for defence purchases'. The Minister is right, but I have no recollection that, in the context of welfare policy, people have said, `In six years' time, you may if you are still alive be fortunate to get those sorts of benefits'.
—We will be in government.
—Order!

—No, we are not fools. The people of Australia are not fools. The obvious reason the Government goes so far ahead is that it can make those sorts of commitments knowing full well that the likelihood of its ever having to be absolutely required to follow them through is extremely low. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) will not be in this chamber, probably the Minister will not be here-he will have retired to better pastures-and probably half the Parliament will not be here either.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that people will not believe governments that make commitments six years down the road. On the record of the Government's social security policy, on the record of the Government's policy in relation to superannuation, the Government is lucky to be able to last 12 months without completely unscrambling its policy. To start with a conception that the Government has introduced a lower tax mix for retirement income in Australia is an absolute falsehood. What the Government has done is to increase tax on superannuation over the last six, nearly seven, years by some 1,000 per cent. That is the record of this Government. That is the reality and that is again what the Government will be tested on in the final analysis by the Australian people.

I am pleased that rent assistance has been increased. For people living in Sydney who are totally dependent on the pension, it is perfectly obvious that the current arrangements were not satisfactory. But I am concerned that I do not know why the Government takes such a narrow approach to this issue when the realities are that there is a supply and demand problem which is forcing up the cost of rents. What that simply means is that, by giving subsidies for higher rental payments, all the Government will effectively be doing will be increasing the level of rent, and not necessarily increasing the level of supply of cheap rental accommodation. That is one of the problems that have to be faced by this Government. I regret to say that the statement made by the Minister tonight gives us absolutely no reason to presume that anything will be done.

Then we have seen in other areas of the policy announced tonight, the superannuation area in particular, how the Government has utilised a number of our new proposals. Again, I think this is a compliment to us. We put it on the public record and the Government has seen fit to support our policy. We commend the Government for having had the intelligence to do precisely that. The point is made, however, that the policy is to be fair to everyone. I suppose it can be said that in many respects fairness is very much in the eye of the beholder. But I am more than surprised that when I read the statement and accompanying documents-and I still have not, I might add, read the document from the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner which may give some light to the subject because I have not received the document yet, regrettably-they bring out some very interesting points.

The first point I want to make is this: Of the increase in expenditure in the social security budget of some $1.7 billion, no less than $700m is in fact being spread in the retirement area. As I said, much of that in fact is on the never-never principle, right through to 1995. But it should be noted that under the taxation arrangements of this Government since June of last year the Government has been taking from the pockets and from the funds of the 1.6 million Australians who have superannuation, between $900m and $1,000m in additional tax. That is the record of the Government. So in two Budgets the Government is getting about $2 billion tax out of long-term savings the need for which we heard the Treasurer tonight speaking about so eloquently. So the Government has taken out $2,000m in tax and has made a miserable contribution on the never-never principle of a mere $700m. Again the Australian taxpayers are not fools. The people who belong to superannuation schemes are not fools. They are going to do their own analyses and they are going to wonder why this Government talks so big about the need for savings when in fact it attacks and it screws the very last dollar it possibly can out of the very people whom it claims on this occasion to be trying to support. Consequently talk about real sustainable increases in incomes coming from a Government which over seven years has done beautifully at reducing people's real income is, to put it mildly, rather far fetched. But those are the words in the Minister's statement; that is what he expects people to believe, and it is my duty, and the duty of my colleagues, to absolutely nail him to the wall and to let people see him for what he really is.

The Treasurer made a point about equality. Everyone is going to have access to superannuation. Let us look at the role of women in relation to superannuation. Many thousands of words have been uttered in this chamber on all sides about the gross inequity which we have had in the superannuation system for far too long, inequity which has been biased principally against women. Their level of coverage is extremely low. But we are told by the Minister, `Don't worry about that. Women who have time out of the work force or who work part time will have access to superannuation'. Now I was fascinated to read that. I thought, `Great. This is again one of the Liberal-National Party proposals which the Government has taken up and this is tremendous'. So I looked through all the documentation for the words `retirement savings account', which of course was the very mechanism, the vehicle which we put forward as the means by which women who have broken careers would be able to do this, so that over a period they would be able to sustain their retirement benefits and get a decent level of retirement income.

When I read the background documents I get all this hyperbole, bureaucratic nonsense and socialist jingo about the terrors of offering those sorts of packages to women who have husbands who can afford to fund their superannuation. That should not be permitted! That is a terrible thing! So the Government has come up with this extraordinary proposal that you can be covered provided you only stay out of the work force for two years. If the Government had done its sums on this, and regrettably it clearly has not, it would have found one interesting thing.

Most women in the child-bearing ages tend to bunch up their children in the sense that they tend to have children reasonably close together. If the Government is going to lock them out of long-term retirement savings on the basis that if they stay out for more than two years they are neutralised, it has absolutely killed the very objective of its policy, which I thought, from the language here, was to give women fair access to superannuation in the Australian system. We did not make that mistake. We said that women who are in employment with superannuation and who leave for family reasons with the intention of going back into the work force should have the right to be covered for those years.

The fact is that most women will probably stay out of the work force for between three and five years, and not two years. That is all the Government has offered them. What the Government has effectively done, therefore, is once again put a major log jam in the way of the people having children in this country. Now people are going to say, `I am going to lose my superannuation if I have children. I am not going to have it long enough if I want to stay at home with those kids for the first couple of years of their lives'. The Government has not achieved a worthwhile policy objective by going down the route it has. If it had taken retirement savings accounts and the broader concept that we put forward, the whole situation would have been far more sensible. To talk about a fairer policy for many thousands of women is nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-One of the major achievements of the Hawke Labor Government has been to improve the situation and future prospects of young Australians. This Government has put in place a solid foundation for the future for Australia's young people. Since 1983 the Government has implemented a wide range of reforms which have radically altered the nature of assistance provided to young people and the ways in which that assistance is delivered. Our aim has been to encourage young people to greater participation in education and training. We wanted to work in partnership with young people and their parents to make sure that our young people had better educational opportunities, adequate income support and better job prospects.

SPEECH.PARA: Our achievements have been considerable. When we came to office in 1983 unemployment among young people was the highest ever recorded with almost one in three out of work. Since then this Government has halved the numbers of young unemployed. There were 141,200 teenagers looking for a job in 1983. Today there are 72,300, an improvement of over 50 per cent. There were 147,500 20-to 24-year-olds looking for a job. Today there are 78,100, again a 50 per cent improvement. At the end of the 1982 school year only 36 per cent of students continued on to year 12. At the end of 1988, 58 per cent were staying at school to year 12. This is a record high level of retention.

We have achieved a major overhaul of our youth income support arrangements. Austudy pay rates, for example, for 16-and 17-year-olds have more than doubled since 1985. The Job Search allowance has encouraged young people into labour market programs and the young homeless allowances was introduced in 1986 as a first step in assisting young homeless people. Opportunities in higher education have been increased significantly. Since 1983 we have created an additional 46,000 higher education places and by 1991 an additional 49,000 will be available.

The numbers of apprentices have risen by over 50 per cent to 54,000 annually and 32,000 young people have benefited from the Australian traineeship system. Under the supported accommodation assistance program we have provided support for up to 2,000 young people every night with accommodation, counselling and information. We have established youth access centres to provide a comprehensive information, advice and referral service for young people. These improvements in the lives and future prospects of young Australians have been achieved because the Hawke Labor Government has developed and put in place the most comprehensive, the most progressive and the most successful strategy for young people in Australia's history.

It is a strategy and that is the key to this Government's approach to the problems and needs of young Australians. In the last year before we came to office 80,000 jobs held by teenagers disappeared, and 288,000 young Australians had unemployment as their only occupation. The Government's strategy has halved this number. A disgraceful 36 per cent of school students stayed on until year 12 in 1983, and the Government strategy has increased this retention to a record of nearly 58 per cent, as I have mentioned.

When we came to office we set in train a period of consultation and review of the impact of our policies for young Australians, underpinned by this Government's commitment to improving the quality of life for all Australians. Following this the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced in 1985 the Government's strategy for young people. The major objectives of the strategy have been to provide all young people with an appropriate combination of a full secondary education, structured training or post-secondary education opportunities, and appropriate income support where necessary. Since then the Government has continued to modify and revise its youth strategy in light of the community's and young people's views and ideas, and in response to the changing economic circumstances that confront young people.

The driving force behind these changes has been the Government's determination to meet the economic challenges that face Australia. The guiding principle of these changes has been the Hawke Labor Government's unswerving commitment to social justice for all Australians. The four main aims of our social justice strategy are: a fair distribution of economic resources; equal access to essential services such as housing, health care and education; equal rights in civil, legal and industrial affairs; and the opportunity for participation by all in personal development, community life and decision making.

Social justice under Labor is a clear statement that achieving a just and equitable society need not be at odds with taking the hard economic decisions necessary for Australia's future. It is young Australians who will have the task of carrying forward critical economic and social reforms. It is young Australians who have benefited and will continue to benefit from those reforms. In October 1988, in line with our commitment to social justice, together with my colleague the Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Social Justice (Mr Howe) I announced a major review of the Government's youth strategy from a social justice perspective. In announcing this review the Government recognised that social justice cannot be achieved by a single program by the simple measure of dollars spent or by a simple statistical measure of poverty. An example of the strength of those initiatives is clear in terms of how we will respond to the needs of homeless young people.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report, Our Homeless Children, is a timely reminder of the pressing need to assist young people who do not have access to stable and secure accommodation. In line with key recommendations of the report, the Government will be placing major priority on further expanding the supply of secure accommodation for young people so that they can escape homelessness or dependence on short term crisis accommodation. This will involve shifting the balance of service delivery away from the present concentration on crisis accommodation towards longer term, more secure accommodation provision and related support for young people.

The Government will increase the number of medium and long term beds available, and improve the adequacy and accessibility of income support for homeless young people. Such improvements will not, however, create undue incentives for young people to leave home or school. We will expand mediation services to assist families stay together, provide innovative health services which will address the particular health problems that flow from homelessness, expand the number of youth access centres that will act as referral and co-ordination points for services directed to meet the needs of homeless young people and, most importantly, provide access to employment and training opportunities that will provide homeless young people with the ability to establish independent and stable living arrangements.

A key element of the Government's approach to meeting the needs of homeless young people will be to seek a cooperative approach from State and from Territory governments. This is in line with the shared responsibility between all levels of government in providing the necessary services. The youth initiatives announced tonight by the Treasurer extend and refine the Government's existing youth strategy. Budget Related Paper No. 9, Towards Social Justice for Young Australians, fully explains those initiatives. An outline of our achievements up until now is contained in the companion booklet, the Federal Government's strategy for young Australians-the Youth Book. Mr Deputy Speaker, I table a copy of the Youth Book.

The Government's youth strategy illustrates our continued commitment to meeting the needs of Australia's young people. It is guided by our determination to achieve a just and equitable society. We have a clear vision of what assistance young people need as they make their transition to full participation in the social and economic life of the community. We have a coherent strategy to provide that assistance. We are prepared to listen to young people and the community and modify that strategy in light of changing circumstances. Government alone cannot change community attitudes to disadvantaged young people.

We need the support and cooperation of the whole of the Australian community. To be serious about turning the ideal of social justice for Australian youth into reality we must approach the task in a systematic and coordinated way. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(b) The Government is studying all of the recommendations contained in the report. Delays in the federal and ACT courts are not as serious as in New South Wales, though the Government is nevertheless taking steps to tackle the delays that do exist. Although provision is made for jury trials in the Federal Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, jury trials have never been conducted in the Federal Court and are no longer conducted in civil cases in the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 16 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the capital cost of constructing (a) new roadways in the car parking area and (b) an office for car parking attendants at Launceston Airport.
(2) What is the projected annual cost of collecting car parking fees at this Airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The capital cost of constructing new roadways and associated pavement alterations in the car park at Launceston Airport was $84,135.
(b) The capital cost of constructing an office for car parking attendants was $46,790.

(2) Staff at the airport work on a variety of functions including traffic, security and revenue collection. The portion of existing salaries attributable to car parking revenue collection is estimated to total $125,000. The Corporation's parking revenue collection involves additional costs of approximately $20,000 which include the depreciation of equipment and facilities and the cost of tickets.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 May 1989 (Hansard, page 2199) the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) asked me, as Minister for Housing and Aged Care, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: How much has been spent on publicising the change from brand name to generic pharmaceuticals, which took place on 1 April? In particular, how much did it cost to produce and distribute to doctors and pharmacists the so-called information package contained in an over-sized plastic pill?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Final costings are not available at this stage for the total publicity campaign because a number of payment invoices are still outstanding. However, on the basis of payments made to date, along with estimates of outstanding commitments provided by the Office of Government Information and Advertising, the final cost of the generic advertising campaign is estimated at $636,000. This includes:
all pamphlets and letters;
newspapers advertisements;
consultancy fees;
talent fees; and
all printing, distribution, design, and artwork.
The cost of the plastic information package and contents was $75,903. This is a final cost figure and includes production, distribution, printing and agency on-costs.
